{{BLP sources|date=June 2011}}{{Infobox person | name = Hugo Sigman | image = Hugo-sigman.png | birth_date = 1944 | birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] | occupation = CEO of Grupo Insud | net_worth = {{increase}}US$1.6 billion (June 2018, jointly with wife)<ref>{{cite web |title=Las 50 personas más ricas de la Argentina según la revista Forbes |url=https://www.infobae.com/economia/finanzas-y-negocios/2018/06/04/las-50-personas-mas-ricas-de-la-argentina-segun-la-revista-forbes/ |website=infobae.com |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref> | spouse = Silvia Gold | website = {{url|hugosigman.com}} }}
'''Hugo Sigman''' is the founder, CEO and –jointly with his wife, Biochemist Silvia Gold— the only shareholder of [[Grupo Insud]], a business conglomerate with an active presence in the fields of pharmaceuticals, agroforestry, culture, nature and design.
==Biographical data and experience==
Hugo Sigman was born in Buenos Aires, [[Argentina]], in 1944. He completed his primary and secondary schooling in public schools. In 1969, he earned his Medical Doctor degree from [[Universidad de Buenos Aires]], and in the same year, he graduated from the Social Psychology School led by [[Enrique Pichon-Rivière|Dr. Pichon Riviére]].
In 1970, he joined as Resident the Psychiatry Service of Policlínico Lanús, directed by Professor Mauricio Goldenberg. He continued his career, first as Chief of Residents, and then as founder and director of the Psychiatric Emergency Unit at the same hospital. In 1976, he moved to [[Spain]], where he worked at the Psychiatry Service of Hospital Clínico de Barcelona.
At that time, encouraged by his father-in-law Roberto Gold, Hugo Sigman started his entrepreneurial career and got involved in the pharmaceutical industry. In 1978, with his wife, Silvia Gold –his partner in love and work for 45 years-, he founded Chemo, a chemical-pharmaceutical company, and the first company of Grupo Insud. Their goal was to create a company to produce high-quality medicines at affordable prices. In the 1980s, Hugo and Silvia returned to Argentina to continue the path they had started in Europe.
==Life Sciences==
At present, Grupo Insud comprises three companies in the life sciences industry: Chemo, a company that sells active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) and finished dosage forms (FDFs) to 1,200 pharmaceutical companies around the world, has 15 manufacturing sites and 9 R&D centers; Exeltis, a company that sells branded products in more than 40 countries, and mAbxience, a biotech company created in 2008, with 3 manufacturing sites, the first monoclonal antibody plant in Latin America –pharmADN- and the first vaccine and biotech production plant in Argentina, Sinergium Biotech.
Chemo signed an agreement with the [[World Health Organization]] and [[Utrecht University]] to produce the Palivizumab [[monoclonal antibody]] and facilitate access to this medicine for premature children, as it is estimated that 250,000 premature children die every year around the world without treatment due to its high cost.<ref>[http://press.uu.nl/cooperation-between-utrecht-university-and-who-for-affordable-medicines-in-developing-countries/ Utrecht University. Cooperation for affordable medicines in developing countries]</ref>
Jointly with renowned Argentine companies, in 2011 Hugo Sigman founded the Argentine Chamber of Biotechnology, Cámara Argentina de Biotecnología, which he currently chairs. The goal of CAB is to strengthen the public-private collaboration policy in biotechnology and encourage its development in the region. In Argentina’s veterinary industry, he is a partner of Biogénesis Bagó, which runs a world-class facility for foot-and-mouth disease vaccine production, the only one that has been authorized by the government of China to build a plant in that country.<ref>[http://www.telam.com.ar/notas/201310/35611-la-planta-de-biogenesis-bago-en-china-sera-la-primera-firma-extranjera-dedicada-a-producir-vacunas-en-china.html Primera firma extranjera dedicada a producir vacunas en china]</ref>
For 20 years, Hugo and Silvia have led the Public-Private Consortium for Research and Development of Innovative Oncology Therapies, which developed the first therapeutic vaccine against lung cancer, [[Racotumomab]] (Vaxira),<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cacciavillano | first1 = W | last2 = Sampor | first2 = C | last3 = Venier | first3 = C | last4 = Gabri | first4 = MR | last5 = de Dávila | first5 = MT | last6 = Galluzzo | first6 = ML | last7 = Guthmann | first7 = MD | last8 = Fainboim | first8 = L | last9 = Alonso | first9 = DF | last10 = Chantada | first10 = GL | date = Jul 2015 | title = A phase I study of the anti-idiotype vaccine racotumomab in neuroblastoma and other pediatric refractory malignancies | url = | journal = Pediatr Blood Cancer | volume = 62| issue = | pages = 2120–4| doi = 10.1002/pbc.25631 | pmid = 26154941 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Reichert | first1 = JM | year = 2015 | title = Antibodies to watch in 2015 | journal = MAbs. | volume = 7 | issue = 1| pages = 1–8 | doi = 10.4161/19420862.2015.988944 | pmid = 25484055 | pmc=4622967}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hernández | first1 = AM | last2 = Vázquez | first2 = AM | date = Jan 2015 | title = Racotumomab-alum vaccine for the treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer | url = | journal = Expert Rev Vaccines | volume = 14 | issue = 1| pages = 9–20 | doi = 10.1586/14760584.2015.984691 | pmid = 25420897 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gajdosik | first1 = Z | date = Apr 2014 | title = Racotumomab - a novel anti-idiotype monoclonal antibody vaccine for the treatment of cancer | url = | journal = Drugs Today (Barc). | volume = 50 | issue = 4| pages = 301–7 | doi = 10.1358/dot.2014.50.4.2116670 | pmid = 24918647 }}</ref> introduced in 2013, and which currently has five new products in research.
In this framework, Hugo Sigman strongly supports public-private partnerships, which he views as a positive paradigm to be promoted with ethics and transparency. He understands that public research centers should give back to society by contributing their knowledge and developments, and the private sector should recognize that contribution by compensating them accordingly. Inspired in that model, he has built partnerships with prestigious institutions including Universidad de Buenos Aires, [[Universidad Nacional de Quilmes]], [[Universidad Nacional de San Martín]], Roffo and [[Garrahan]] Hospitals, [[:es:Academia Nacional de Medicina (Argentina)|Academia Nacional de Medicina]], and several foreign universities.
Approximately 250 researchers work at the partnerships supported by the Group, doing basic and applied research; 100 of them are dedicated to the development of products for treating cancer.
==Agribusiness==
His entrepreneurial spirit and interest in biology have led Hugo Sigman beyond the frontiers of the pharmaceutical industry. In 1998, he started agricultural and forestry activities in different locations of Argentina, focused on genetic improvement and sustainable production, with companies Garruchos, devoted to farming and cattle-raising; Pomera, ranked as the top Argentine-capital forestry company; and Cabaña Los Murmullos, a leading cattle breeding ranch. Sigman is also a shareholder of Bioceres, an Argentine [[biotechnology]] company focused on agricultural production. This young company developed a gene that enables the production of wheat, corn and soybean resistant to draughts and soil salinity, and has licensed its products to the USA, France and India.
==Communication and Art==
Hugo Sigman encourages the exchange of ideas through publishing company Capital intellectual, which includes a line of publications in Spain under the publishing brand Clave Intellectual, the Southern Cone edition of Le Monde Diplomatique, and the Latin American version of prestigious The New York Review of Books. In 2005, Hugo Sigman partnered with [[Oscar Kramer]] and established filmmaking company Kramer&Sigman Films (K&S), which has grown to be a thriving production company, with several box-office successes, including ''[[Kamchatka (film)|Kamchatka]]'', ''[[El perro]]'', ''The Last Elvis'', ''Seventh Floor'', ''[[Wild Tales (film)|Wild Tales]]''.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/satirical-wild-tales-stands-out-among-oscars-foreign-language-nominees/2015/02/25/37cdfdc4-b880-11e4-9423-f3d0a1ec335c_story.html Satirical ‘Wild Tales’ stands out among Oscar’s foreign language nominees] [[Washington Post]].</ref>
===Wild tales===
Produced by Hugo Sigman for Kramer& Sigman Films and by [[El Deseo]] ([[Pedro Almodóvar]] and [[Agustín Almodóvar]] ’s production company), ''[[Wild Tales (film)|Wild Tales]]'' (Relatos Salvajes) was directed by [[Damián Szifron]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/movies/s/ap-interview-damian-szifron-lives-own-wild-tale-234109186.html |title=Damian Szifron lives his own wild tale |author=Sigal Ratner-Arias |date=January 16, 2015 |publisher=[[Associasted Press|AP]]}}</ref> starring [[Ricardo Darín]],<ref>[http://varietylatino.com/video/relatos-salvajes-entrevista-ricardo-darin-cannes-video/ Interview with Ricardo Darin, Variety Latino]</ref> Julieta Zylberberg, Rita Cortese; [[Darío Grandinetti]]; [[Érica Rivas]]; [[Oscar Martínez (actor)|Oscar Martínez]] and [[Leonardo Sbaraglia]]. Co-produced by Telefé and Corner, and distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures, Wild Tales exceeded 1 million tickets sold in its first ten days of screening.<ref>[http://elpais.com/elpais/2014/10/01/inenglish/1412192871_297010.html Going wild at the Argentinean box office] [[El País]]</ref>
An art and culture enthusiast, between 2010 and 2013, Hugo Sigman was a member of the Advisory Council of the [[National Fine Arts Museum of Argentina]], and is currently a member of the Board of Patronage of [[Museo Reina Sofía]], in Madrid, Spain. Additionally, the venue of Grupo INSUD in Buenos Aires (the traditional Díaz Vélez Palace), built in 1907 and recently restored, has won several architectural awards and has been declared a protected heritage site of Buenos Aires City.<ref>[http://socearq.org/2.0/2015/03/26/visita-al-edificio-insud-nueva-sede-coorporativa/, Sociedad Central de Arquitectos]</ref>
==Social Responsibility: Mundo Sano Foundation==
Hugo and Silvia have always had a strong commitment to give back to society. This social responsibility is infused in their work with the Mundo Sano Foundation.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/health-29343210 Chagas disease - inheriting a silent killer] [[BBC]]</ref> in Argentina, Spain and Ethiopia,<ref>[http://www.mundosano.org/en/press-communications/from-salta-to-ethiopia-mundo-sano-replicates-its-original-work-in-the-fight-against-soil-transmitted-helminths/ From Salta to Ethiopia: Mundo Sano replicates its original work in the fight against soil-transmitted helminths]</ref> with the vision to transform the reality of populations affected by [[neglected tropical diseases]] (NTDs) including [[Chagas disease|Chagas]], [[dengue]] and [[soil-transmitted helminths]].<ref>[http://www.gatesfoundation.org/Media-Center/Press-Releases/2014/04/Global-Partners-Are-Taking-the-Neglect-out-of-Neglected-Tropical-Diseases Global Partners Are Taking the "Neglect" out of "Neglected Tropical Diseases"] [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]]</ref>
==International Awards and Accolades==
In 2015, Hugo Sigman received the [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Entrepreneur of the Year Award]], from [http://www.ey.com/ EY] consulting firm (Ernst & Young) in Argentina.<ref>[http://www.sigmanhugo.com.ar/index.php?cID=1455 Hugo Sigman, Entrepreneur of the Year] [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]</ref>
In 2013, the [[Endeavor (non-profit)|Endeavor]] Foundation named him the "Model Entrepreneur" for his values and track record. In 2008, he received the merit diploma at the [[Konex Award]]s, in the "Innovative Entrepreneurs" category. In 2011, jointly with Silvia Gold, he received an award from Asociación de Dirigentes de Empresa (ADE) in the "Agroindustry" category.
Sigman presented the achievements of the Research, Development and Innovation Consortium at Experience Endeavor in August 2013, and at the 11th International Symposium on AIDS, organized by Fundación Huésped, in 2012.
In April 2012, he was a speaker at the Global Investment Forum, organized by the [[United Nations]] in [[Qatar]].<ref>[http://unctadxiii.org/en/Daily%20Journal/uxiii_journal_no2_en.pdf Programme of meetings, april 2012, Journal UNCTAD XIII, Doha, Qatar]</ref> He presented the state-of-the-art productive investment model based on partnerships with other pharmaceutical companies and public entities.
In September 2011, Sigman was guest speaker at the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] held in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. His lecture was about the manufacturing of vaccines and biotechnologicals in Argentina. ''The Sinergium Biotech model of integration for the production of vaccines and biotech products involves technology transfer, export potential and the creation of 320 jobs,'' said Sigman. Also in 2011, Sigman delivered a presentation on global entrepreneurship at the 47th IDEA Colloquium.
In 2009, Sigman took part in the 15th Conference of the [[Argentine Industrial Union]], and was guest speaker representing Argentina at [[Harvard]] and [[Columbia University|Columbia]] Universities.

'''Insulated shipping containers''' are a type of [[packaging]] used to ship temperature sensitive products such as [[food]]s, [[pharmaceutical]]s, [[Organ (anatomy)|organs]], [[blood]], biologic materials, and [[chemical]]s. They are used as part of a [[cold chain]] to help maintain product freshness and efficacy. The term can also refer to [[Thermal insulation|insulated]] [[intermodal container]]s or insulated [[Swap body|swap bodies]].
==Construction== [[File:Cold control packaging.jpg|thumb |Shipment of vaccine: PUR insulated box, gel packs, temperature monitor]] A variety of constructions have been developed. <ref> {{cite patent | number =US5924302A | title =Insulated shipping container | pubdate =1999 | inventor =Deerfield | url =https://patents.google.com/patent/US5924302A/en }}</ref> <ref> {{cite patent | number =US5201868A | title =Insulated shipping container | pubdate =1993 | inventor =Johnson | url =https://patents.google.com/patent/US5201868A/en }}</ref> <ref> {{cite patent | number =US6868982B2 | title =Insulated shipping container and method of making the same | pubdate =2005 | inventor =Gordon | url =https://patents.google.com/patent/US6868982B2/en }}</ref><ref> {{cite patent | number =US6119465A | title =Shipping container for storing materials at cryogenic temperatures | pubdate =2000 | inventor =Mullens | url =https://patents.google.com/patent/US6119465A/en }}</ref> An insulated [[shipping container]] might be constructed of: # a [[vacuum flask]], similar to a "thermos" bottle # fabricated thermal blankets or liners # molded expanded [[polystyrene]] foam (EPS, [[expanded polystyrene foam|styrofoam]]), similar to a [[cooler]] # other molded foams such as [[polyurethane]], [[polyethylene]] # sheets of foamed plastics # [[Vacuum insulated panel|Vacuum Insulated Panels]] (VIPs) # reflective materials: ([[metallised film]]) # [[bubble wrap]] or other gas filled panels # other packaging materials and structures
Some are designed for single use while others are returnable for [[reuse]]. Some insulated containers are decommissioned refrigeration units. Some empty containers are sent to the shipper disassembled or “knocked down”, assembled and used, then knocked down again for easier return shipment.
Shipping containers are available for maintaining cryogenic temperatures, with the use of liquid nitrogen. Some carriers have these as a specialized service<ref>https://www.ups.com/us/en/services/healthcare/healthcare-products/temperature-true-cryo.page</ref>
==Use== [[File:Using Insulated Shipping Containers and Validated Packing Protocols technical-3.theora.ogv|thumbnail|left|[[United States Army Medical Materiel Agency]] video showing how containers are packed to maintain constant cold temperatures.]] Insulated shipping containers are part of a comprehensive cold chain which controls and documents the temperature of a product through its entire distribution cycle. The containers may be used with a refrigerant or coolant such as:<ref>{{cite journal |last=Matsunaga |first= K|authorlink= |author2=Burgess, Lockhart |date=March 2007 |title=Two methods for calculating the amount of refrigerant required for cyclic temperature testing of insulated packages |journal=Packaging Technology and Science |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages=113–123 |doi=10.1002/pts.747 |url= |accessdate= |quote= }}</ref> * block or cube [[ice]], [[slurry ice]] * [[dry ice]] * Gel or [[ice pack]]s (often formulated for specific temperature ranges) * [[Phase-change material|Phase change materials]] (PCMs) * Some products (such as frozen meat) have sufficient thermal mass to contribute to the temperature control and no excess coolant is required
A digital [[Temperature data logger]] or a [[time temperature indicator]] is often enclosed to monitor the temperature inside the container for its entire shipment.
[[Label]]s and appropriate documentation (internal and external) are usually required.
Personnel throughout the cold chain need to be aware of the special handling and documentation required for some controlled shipments. With some regulated products, complete documentation is required.
==Design and Evaluation== The use of “off the shelf” insulated shipping containers does not necessarily guarantee proper performance. Several factors need to be considered:<ref>{{cite journal |last=Choi |first= Seung-Jin|authorlink= |author2=Burgess |date=November 2007 |title=Practical mathematical model to predict the performance of insulating packages|journal=Packaging Technology and Science |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=369–380 |doi=10.1002/pts.762 |url= |accessdate= |quote= }}</ref>
* the sensitivity of the product to temperatures (high and low) and to time at temperatures * the specific distribution system being used: the expected (and worst case) time and temperatures * regulatory requirements * the specific combination of packaging components and materials being used
In specifying an insulated shipping container, the two primary characteristics of the material are its [[thermal conductivity]] or [[R-value (insulation)|R-value]], and its thickness. These two attributes will help determine the resistance to heat transfer from the ambient environment into the payload space. The coolant material load temperature, quantity, [[latent heat]], and [[sensible heat]] will help determine the amount of heat the parcel can absorb while maintaining the desired control temperature. Combining the attributes from the insulator and coolant will allow analysis of expected duration of the insulated shipping container system.
It is wise (and sometimes mandatory) to have formal [[Verification and validation|verification]] of the performance of the insulated shipping container. Laboratory [[package testing]] might include [[ASTM]] D3103-07, Standard Test Method for Thermal Insulation Performance of Packages, ISTA Guide 5B: Focused Simulation Guide for Thermal Performance Testing of Temperature Controlled Transport Packaging, and others.<ref> {{cite journal | last = Singh | first = S P | last2 = Burgess, Singh | date = 2008 | title = Performance Comparison of Thermal Insulated Packaging Boxes, Bags and Refrigerants for Single-parcel Shipments | url = https://digitalcommons.calpoly.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0,24&qsp=6&q=gel+pack+packaging&httpsredir=1&article=1043&context=it_fac | journal =Packaging Technology and Science | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 25-35 | doi = | access-date = 9 Oct 2018 }}</ref> In addition, [[Verification and Validation|validation]] of field performance (performance qualification) is extremely useful.
Specialists in design and testing of packaging for temperature sensitive products are often needed. These may be consultants, independent laboratories, universities, or reputable vendors. Many laboratories have certifications and accreditations: [[ISO 9000]]s, [[ISO/IEC 17025]], etc.
== Environmental Impact == Parcel to pallet sized insulated shipping containers have historically been single-use products due to the low-cost material composition of EPS and water-based gel packs. The insulation material typically finds its way into landfill streams as it is not readily recyclable in the United States.
The development of reusable high-performance shipping containers have been shown to reduce packing waste by 95% while also contributing significant savings to other environmental pollutants.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goellner|first=Kai N.|last2=Sparrow|first2=Eph|date=2013-11-26|title=An environmental impact comparison of single-use and reusable thermally controlled shipping containers|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11367-013-0668-z|journal=The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment|language=en|volume=19|issue=3|pages=611–619|doi=10.1007/s11367-013-0668-z|issn=0948-3349}}</ref>

{{further|Water supply and sanitation in the Republic of Ireland}} [[Water supply and sanitation in the Republic of Ireland|Water supplies in Ireland]] are governed by the Water Services Acts of 2007 to 2014. Until 2015, this legislation provided for the provision of water and wastewater services by [[Local government in the Republic of Ireland|local authorities]], with domestic usage funded through central taxation, and non-domestic usage funded via local authority [[Rates (tax)|rates]]. Under terms of a 2010 [[Economic Adjustment Programme for Ireland|Economic Adjustment (Bailout) Programme]], the then government agreed to change this arrangement.{{cite news|url= http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/government-forced-by-troika-to-set-up-irish-water-too-early-1.1668688 |publisher= Irish Times |title= Government ‘forced by Troika’ to set up Irish Water too early |date= 26 January 2014}} From 2015, legislation came into force such that a new utility company, Irish Water, became responsible for providing water and wastewater services, with the intention that the company would be funded through direct billing. water in County Donegal.{{cite news|url= http://www.irishtimes.com/news/environment/epa-suing-irish-water-and-council-over-water-standard-in-letterkenny-1.1950143 | publisher=Irish Times |title=EPA suing Irish Water and council over water standard in Letterkenny |date=3 October 2014}} In 2014 and 2015, local protests were encouraged by residents across the country, and supported by [[Sinn Féin]], [[Socialist Party]], [[Socialist Workers Party (Ireland)|Socialist Workers Party]], [[Eirigi]], [[Republican Sinn Féin]], [[32 County Sovereignty Movement]], [[Communist Party of Ireland]], [[Workers' Party of Ireland|Workers' Party]], [[Workers Solidarity Movement]], [[Direct Democracy Ireland]] along with trade unionists and other civil society organisations. Those opposed to the plans physically blocked the installation of water meters and demonstrated against the introduction of water charges. A demonstration that took place in [[Dublin]] on 11 October 2014 involved approximately 130,000 (4% of Ireland's population).{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} The ''[[Irish Times]]'' newspaper conducted a poll the week before which found that 33% of people intended to boycott water charges. Also on 11 October, [[Paul Murphy (Irish politician)|Paul Murphy]], an anti-austerity candidate, won the Dublin-West by-election. This resulted in journalist [[Fintan O'Toole]] to describe 11 October 2014 as the 'Water Rebellion'.{{cite web |url=http://www.irishcentral.com/opinion/cahirodoherty/120000-Irish-protest-as-the-good-boys-of-Europe-turn-bad.html |title=120,000 Irish protest as the good boys of Europe turn bad |publisher=IrishCentral.com |date=2014-11-02 |accessdate=2015-07-29}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/20/opinion/fintan-otoole-the-irish-rebellion-over-water.html?_r=0 |title=The Irish Rebellion Over Water | publisher=New York Times |date= 19 December 2014}} Further demonstrations took place in key provincial towns and cities in November 2014, and on 10 December 2014 approximately 100,000 people protested in Dublin against water charges, with the [[Gardaí]] (police) setting up barricades to establish a seclusion zone around government buildings. In response protestors blockaded roads and bridges in the city centre, postponing bus services, until the early hours of the next morning. Community groups set up to oppose water meters also reportedly physically removed water meters in the days after the protest.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/dublin-brought-to-standstill-by-water-protest-1.2032874 |title=Dublin brought to standstill by water protest |publisher=Irishtimes.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/environment/traffic-eases-after-tens-of-thousands-protest-against-water-charges-1.2032524 |title=Traffic eases after tens of thousands protest against water charges |publisher=Irishtimes.com |date=2014-12-10 |accessdate=2015-07-29}} The utility and associated charges were also a feature in the [[Irish general election, 2016|2016 general election]], with a number of parties and candidates campaigning specifically on the issue.{{cite news|url= http://www.independent.ie/breaking-news/irish-news/election-candidates-join-thousands-in-dublin-protest-against-water-charges-34470717.html | publisher =Independent News & Media |date= 20 February 2016 | title= Election candidates join thousands in Dublin protest against water charges }} Water charges were suspended in the months following the election,{{cite web|url= http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/billing-of-water-charges-to-be-suspended-next-week-1.2698891 | publisher= Irish Times |date= 24 June 2016 | title= Billing of water charges to be suspended next week }} and an 'expert commission on the funding of water services' established to assess the issue. The commission published a report on 29 November 2016 which recommended that normal household water usage should be paid for by the State, with excessive usage paid for by the consumer in a "polluter pays" model.{{cite web|url= https://www.rte.ie/news/2016/1130/835595-european-commission-water/ | publisher = RTÉ News| date= 30 November 2016 | title= EC to 'evaluate' expert report on water charges }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.water.ie}} [[Category:2014 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Department of Communications, Climate Action and Environment]] [[Category:Post-2008 Irish economic downturn]] [[Category:Water supply and sanitation in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:State-sponsored bodies of the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Waste management in Ireland]]

[[File:Page 123 - Scrambles amongst the Alps - Whymper.jpg|right|thumb|Carrel, as depicted in [[Edward Whymper]]'s memoir ''Scrambles Amongst the Alps'']] [[File:J.A. Carrel.tiff|thumb|upright|Jean-Antoine Carrel]] '''Jean-Antoine Carrel''' (1829 – August 1891) was an Italian [[mountain climber]] and [[mountain guide|guide]]. He had made climbs with [[Edward Whymper]] and was his rival when he attempted to climb the [[Matterhorn]] for the first time. Whymper ultimately succeeded in making the mountain's [[First ascent of the Matterhorn|first ascent]] in July 1865 while Carrel led the party that achieved the [[second ascent of the Matterhorn|second ascent]] three days later. Carrel was in the group that became the first Europeans to reach the summit of [[Chimborazo (volcano)|Chimborazo]] in 1880.<ref name="Gos"/> He died from exhaustion when guiding a party on the south side of the Matterhorn.
==Early life== Carrel was born on 16 January 1829 in [[Valtournenche]], in the [[Aosta Valley]], an [[Arpitan]]-speaking village of [[Kingdom of Sardinia]] (now [[Italy]]) which lies at the foot of the [[Matterhorn]].<ref name=boyslife>{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=02YEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30|title=Whymper allowed a beginner to join his climbing party. He should have known better.|work=[[Boys' Life]]|date=December 1988|page=30}}</ref> He served in the [[Bersaglieri]], a [[light infantry]] unit of the Piedmontese army. He resigned from the Bersaglieri to work as a hunter and [[mountain guide]], but was recalled to duty in 1859 to defend Italy against Austria in the [[Second Italian War of Independence]], for which he won a French medal for the Italian campaign.<ref name=hansen>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eep1B-8JZRkC&pg=PT188|pages=188–189|title=The Summits of Modern Man|last=Hansen|first=Peter H.|publisher=[[Harvard University Press]]|year=2013|isbn=9780674074552}}</ref>
==Ascent of the Matterhorn== {{Main article|Second ascent of the Matterhorn}} Carrel first attempted to climb the Matterhorn's Lion Ridge in 1857—by which time the mountain was the tallest unclimbed peak in the Alps—with his uncle and [[Amé Gorret]]. In the early 1860s, Carrel made numerous attempts to climb the Matterhorn, often in the same party as [[Edward Whymper]] and [[John Tyndall]], and at other times competing against them to reach the summit first.<ref name=hansen/> Carrel had agreed to accompany Whymper on his ascent of the Swiss side in 1865, but withdrew at the last minute when he was recruited by [[Felice Giordano]] on behalf of the [[Italian Alpine Club]] to lead an Italian party up the Italian side at the same time. Ultimately, Whymper's party outclimbed the Italians and reached the summit on 14 July 1865, marking the [[first ascent of the Matterhorn]].<ref name=boyslife/> Carrel and his Italian party successfully summited the Matterhorn three days later.<ref>{{cite book|title=Thin Ice: Unlocking the Secrets of Climate in the World's Highest Mountains|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HGIcabCZHVUC&pg=PA84|first=Mark|last=Bowen|page=84|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]]|year=2006|isbn=9781429932707}}</ref>
==Death== Carrel died in August 1891 while guiding a party on the south side of the Matterhorn.<ref name="Gos">{{cite book|last=Gos|first=Charles|title=Alpine Tragedy|chapter=Carrel the Great|others=Trans. Malcolm Barnes|location=[[New York City|New York]]|publisher=[[Charles Scribner's Sons]]|year=1948|pages=218–228}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0CEED91E31E033A25752C0A96F9C946097D6CF |title=Fatalities of Mountaineering (note that this article, a compendium of mountain accidents over several years, states that Carrel's death occurred in 1890 but this is probably a mistake since 1891 is carved on Carrel's memorial cross) |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 September 1901|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref> After ensuring that his clients descended the mountain safely and easily in a severe storm, he collapsed from exhaustion and died on a rock at the mountain's base.<ref>{{cite book|first=Jonathan|last=Simon|chapter=High Altitude Rescue as Moral Risk and Moral Opportunity|page=383|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YWxDM1v1EFEC&pg=PA383|title=Risk and Morality|year=2003|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=9780802085634}}</ref>
After Carrel's death, Whymper wrote that Carrel was "a man who was possessed with a pure and genuine love of mountains; a man of originality and resource, courage and determination, who delighted in exploration ... The manner of his death strikes a chord in hearts he never knew."<ref>{{cite book|title=Scrambles Amongst the Alps: In the Years 1860–69|first=Edward|last=Whymper|page=418|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k6uScEubYogC&pg=PA418|publisher=Courier Dover Publication|year=1996|isbn=9780486289724}}</ref>

{{distinguish|Pharyngitis}} {{other uses}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Laryngitis | image = Laryngitis gastrica.jpg | caption = Endoscopic image of an inflamed larynx caused by [[acid reflux]] | field = [[Otorhinolaryngology]] | pronounce = {{IPAc-en|ˌ|l|æ|r|ɪ|n|ˈ|dʒ|aɪ|t|ɪ|s}} | image_size = 300px | symptoms = [[Hoarse voice]], fever, pain<ref name=BMJ2014/><ref name=PubMed2016/> | onset = | duration = Usually less than 2 weeks<ref name=BMJ2014/> | causes = Viral, trauma, bacterial<ref name=BMJ2014/> | risks = | diagnosis = Based on symptoms, examination via [[laryngoscopy]] if concerns<ref name=BMJ2014/> | differential = [[Epiglottitis]], [[laryngeal cancer]], [[croup]]<ref name=BMJ2014/> | prevention = | treatment = Voice rest, fluids<ref name=BMJ2014/> | medication = | frequency = Common<ref name=BMJ2014/> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Laryngitis''' is [[inflammation]] of the [[larynx]] (voice box).<ref name=BMJ2014>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.bmj.com/content/349/bmj.g5827|title=Laryngitis|last=Wood|first=John M.|last2=Athanasiadis|first2=Theodore|date=9 October 2014|website=BMJ|publisher=The BMJ|volume=349|pages=g5827|doi=10.1136/bmj.g5827|access-date=21 November 2016|last3=Allen|first3=Jacqui|issn=1756-1833|pmid=25300640|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161113161059/http://www.bmj.com/content/349/bmj.g5827|archivedate=13 November 2016|df=}}</ref> Symptoms often include a [[hoarse voice]] and may include [[fever]], cough, pain in the front of the neck, and [[dysphagia|trouble swallowing]].<ref name=BMJ2014/><ref name=PubMed2016>{{cite web|title=Laryngitis - National Library of Medicine|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMHT0022339/|website=PubMed Health|accessdate=9 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910145257/https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMHT0022339/|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}}</ref> Typically, these last under two weeks.<ref name=BMJ2014/>
<!-- Causes --> Laryngitis is categorised as [[acute (medicine)|acute]] if it lasts less than three weeks and [[chronic (medicine)|chronic]] if symptoms last more than three weeks.<ref name=BMJ2014/> Acute cases usually occur as part of a [[viral upper respiratory tract infection]].<ref name=BMJ2014/> Other infections and trauma such as from coughing are other causes.<ref name=BMJ2014/> Chronic cases may occur due to [[smoking]], [[tuberculosis]], [[allergies]], [[acid reflux]], [[rheumatoid arthritis]], or [[sarcoidosis]].<ref name=BMJ2014/><ref name=Dworkin2008>{{cite journal|last1=Dworkin|first1=James Paul|title=Laryngitis: Types, Causes, and Treatments|journal=Otolaryngologic Clinics of North America|date=April 2008|volume=41|issue=2|pages=419–436|doi=10.1016/j.otc.2007.11.011|pmid=18328379}}</ref> The underlying mechanism involves irritation of the [[vocal folds|vocal cords]].<ref name=PubMed2016/>
<!-- Diagnosis --> Concerning signs that may require further investigation include [[stridor]], history of [[radiation therapy]] to the neck, trouble swallowing, duration of more than three weeks, and a history of smoking.<ref name=BMJ2014/> If concerning signs are present the vocal cords should be examined via [[laryngoscopy]].<ref name=BMJ2014/> Other conditions that can produce similar symptoms include [[epiglottitis]], [[croup]], inhaling a [[foreign body]], and [[laryngeal cancer]].<ref name=BMJ2014/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ferri|first1=Fred F.|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2017: 5 Books in 1|date=2016|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780323448383|page=709|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA709|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110105951/https://books.google.ca/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA709|archivedate=2016-11-10|df=}}</ref>
<!-- Treatment and epidemiology --> The acute form generally resolves without specific treatment.<ref name=BMJ2014/> Resting the voice and sufficient fluids may help.<ref name=BMJ2014/> [[Antibiotic]]s generally do not appear to be useful in the acute form.<ref name=Rev2015>{{cite journal|last1=Reveiz|first1=L|last2=Cardona|first2=AF|title=Antibiotics for acute laryngitis in adults|journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=23 May 2015|volume=5|issue=5|pages=CD004783|pmid=26002823|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004783.pub5}}</ref> The acute form is common while the chronic form is not.<ref name=BMJ2014/> The chronic form occurs most often in middle age and is more common in men than women.<ref name=Dh2014>{{cite book|last1=Dhingra|first1=P. L.|last2=Dhingra|first2=Shruti|title=Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat|date=2014|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9788131236932|page=292|edition=6|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=0ByMBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA292|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110105828/https://books.google.ca/books?id=0ByMBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA292|archivedate=2016-11-10|df=}}</ref> {{TOC limit|3}}
==Signs and symptoms== The primary symptom of laryngitis is a hoarse voice.<ref name=":07"/>{{rp|108}} Because laryngitis can have various causes, other signs and symptoms may vary.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Classification Manual of Voice Disorders-I.|last=|first=|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum|year=2006|isbn=|editor-last=Verdolini|editor-first=Katherine|series=American Speech-Language-Hearing Association|location=Mahwah, N.J|pages=|quote=|editor-last2=Rosen|editor-first2=Clark A.|editor-last3=Branksi|editor-first3=Ryan C.|via=}}</ref> They can include * Dry or sore throat * Coughing (both a causal factor and a symptom of laryngitis) * Frequent throat clearing * Increased saliva production * [[Dysphagia]] (difficulty swallowing) * Sensation of swelling in the area of the [[larynx]] (discomfort in the front of the neck) * [[Globus pharyngis|Globus pharyngeus]] (feeling like there is a lump in the throat) * Cold or [[flu-like symptoms]] (which, like a cough, may also be a causal factor for laryngitis) * Swollen [[lymph node]]s in the throat, chest, or face * Fever * General muscle pain ([[myalgia]]) * [[Dyspnea|Shortness of breath]], predominantly in children
=== Voice quality === Aside from a hoarse-sounding voice, changes to pitch and volume may occur with laryngitis. Speakers may experience a lower or higher pitch than normal, depending on whether their vocal folds are swollen or stiff.<ref name=BMJ2014/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Takahashi|first=H.|last2=Koike|first2=Y.|date=1976|title=Some perceptual dimensions and acoustical correlates of pathologic voices|journal=Acta Oto-Laryngologica Supplementum|volume=|issue=338|pages=1–24}}</ref> They may also have breathier voices, as more air flows through the space between the vocal folds (the [[glottis]]), quieter volume<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shipp|first=Thomas|last2=Huntington|first2=Dorothy A.|date=1965-11-01|title=Some Acoustic and Perceptual Factors in Acute-Laryngitic Hoarseness|url=http://jshd.pubs.asha.org/article.aspx?doi=10.1044/jshd.3004.350|journal=Journal of Speech and Hearing Disorders|volume=30|issue=4|doi=10.1044/jshd.3004.350|pmid=5835492|issn=0022-4677|pages=350}}</ref> and a reduced range.<ref name="BMJ2014"/><ref name="BMJ2014"/>
==Causes== [[File:Laryngitis.png|thumb|upright=1.3|Laryngitis]] Laryngitis can be infectious as well as noninfectious in origin. The resulting inflammation of the vocal folds results in a distortion of the sound produced there.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> It normally develops in response to either an infection, trauma to the vocal folds, or allergies.<ref name="Dworkin2008"/> Chronic laryngitis may also be caused by more severe problems, such as nerve damage, sores, polyps, or hard and thick lumps ([[Vocal fold nodule|nodules]]) on the vocal cords.[[Laryngitis#cite note-4|<sup>[4]</sup>]]
=== Acute ===
==== Viral ==== * Most acute cases of laryngitis are caused by viral infections,<ref name="BMJ2014"/> the most common of which tend to be [[rhinovirus]], [[influenza virus]], [[Human parainfluenza viruses|parainfluenza virus]], [[adenovirus]], [[coronavirus]], and [[Respiratory syncytial virus|RSV]]. In patients who have a compromised immune system, other viruses such as herpes, HIV and [[coxsackievirus]] may also be potential causes.
==== Bacterial ==== * This is another major cause of acute laryngitis, and may develop in conjunction with or due to a viral infection.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> Common bacterial strains are; [[group A streptococcus]], ''[[Streptococcus pneumoniae]]'', ''[[C. diphtheriae]]'', ''[[M. catarrhalis]]'', ''[[Haemophilus influenzae]]'', ''[[Bordetella pertussis]]'', ''[[Bacillus anthracis]]'', and ''[[M. tuberculosis]]''. In developing countries, more unusual bacterial causes may occur such as [[Mycobacterium|mycobacterial]] and [[Syphilis|syphilitic]], though these may occur in developed nations as well.<ref name="BMJ2014" />
==== Fungal ==== * Laryngitis caused by fungal infection is common but not frequently diagnosed according to a review by BMJ and can account for up to 10% of acute laryngitis cases.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> Patients with both functioning and impaired immune systems can develop fungal laryngitis, which may develop as a result of recent antibiotic or inhaled corticosteroids use.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> Certain strains of fungi that may cause laryngitis include; ''[[Histoplasma]]'', ''[[Blastomyces]]'', [[Candida (fungus)|''Candida'']] (especially in immunocompromised persons), and ''[[Cryptococcus]]'' and ''[[Coccidioides]]''.
==== Trauma ==== * Often due to excessive use of the vocal folds such as excessive yelling, screaming, or singing. Though this often results in damage to the outer layers of the vocal folds, the subsequent healing may lead to changes in the physiology of the folds.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> Another potential cause of inflammation may be [[Vocal loading|overuse]] of the vocal cords.[[Laryngitis#cite note-5|<sup>[5]</sup>]] [[Laryngitis#cite note-6|<sup>[6]</sup>]] [[Laryngitis#cite note-7|<sup>[7]</sup>]] [[Laryngitis#cite note-8|<sup>[8]</sup>]] [[Laryngitis#cite note-9|<sup>[9]</sup>]] Laryngeal trauma, including [[iatrogenic]] (caused by [[endotracheal intubation]]), can also result in inflammation of the vocal cords.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rieger|first=A.|last2=Hass|first2=I.|last3=Gross|first3=M.|last4=Gramm|first4=HJ|last5=Eyrich|first5=K.|year=1996|title=Intubation trauma of the larynx--a literature review with special reference to arytenoid cartilage dislocation|journal=Anasthesiol Intensivmed Notfallmed Schmerzther.|volume=31|issue=5|pmid=8767240|doi=10.1055/s-2007-995921|pages=281–7}}</ref>
=== Chronic ===
==== Allergies ==== * Findings are unclear as to whether asthma may cause symptoms commonly associated with laryngitis.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> Some researchers have posited that allergic causes of laryngitis are often misdiagnosed as being the result of acid reflux.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brook|first=Christopher|last2=Platt|first2=Michael|last3=Reese|first3=Stephen|last4=Noordzij|first4=Pieter|date=January 2016|title=Utility of Allergy Testing in Patients with Chronic Laryngopharyngeal Symptoms: Is It Allergic Laryngitis?|journal=Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery|publisher=|volume= 154| issue = 1 |doi=10.1177/0194599815607850|pages=41–45}}</ref>
==== Reflux ==== * One possible explanation of chronic laryngitis is that inflammation is caused by gastro-oesophageal reflux which causes subsequent irritation of the vocal folds.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Joniau|first=Sander|last2=Bradshaw|first2=Anthony|last3=Esterman|first3=Adrian|last4=Carney|first4=A. Simon|date=May 2007|title=Reflux and laryngitis: A systematic review|doi=10.1016/j.otohns.2006.12.004|pmid=17478199|journal=Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery|volume= 136| issue = 5|pages=686–692}}</ref>
==== Autoimmune disorders ==== * Approximately between 30-75% of persons with rheumatoid arthritis report symptoms of laryngitis.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> * Symptoms of laryngitis are present in only 0.5-5% of people that have sarcoidosis.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> According to a meta-analysis by Silva et al. (2007), this disease is often an uncommon cause of laryngeal symptoms and is frequently misdiagnosed as another voice disorder.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Silva|first=Leonardo|last2=Damrose|first2=Edward|last3=Bairao|first3=Fernanda|last4=Nina|first4=Mayra|last5=Junior|first5=James|last6=Costa|first6=Henrique|date=June 2008|title=Infectious granulomatous laryngitis: a retrospective study of 24 cases|journal=European Archives of Oto-Rhino-Laryngology|publisher=|volume= 265| issue = 6|doi=10.1007/s00405-007-0533-4|pages=675–680}}</ref>
==Diagnosis== Diagnosis of different forms of acute laryngitis * Laryngitis following trauma: This form of laryngitis is usually identified by obtaining a case history providing information on previous phono traumatic experiences, internal trauma caused by recent procedures as well as any previous neck injuries.<ref name="BMJ2014" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=House |first=SA |date=December 2017 |title=Hoarseness in Adults |journal=Am Fam Physician |volume=11 |issue=11 |pages=720–728 |pmid=29431404 }}</ref> *Acute viral laryngitis: This form of laryngitis is characterized by lower [[vocal pitch]] as well as [[Hoarse voice|hoarseness]].<ref name="BMJ2014" /><ref name=":0" /> The symptoms in this form of laryngitis are usually present for less than one week, however they can persist for 3-4 weeks.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> This form of laryngitis might also be accompanied by upper respiratory tract symptoms such as: sore throat, [[odynophagia]], [[rhinorrhea]], [[dyspnea]], postnasal discharge, and congestion.<ref name="BMJ2014" />
* Fungal laryngitis: A [[biopsy]] and culture of abnormal lesion may help confirm fungal laryngitis.<ref name="BMJ2014" />
=== Visual diagnosis === The larynx itself will often show [[erythema]] (reddening) and [[edema]] (swelling). This can be seen with [[laryngoscopy]] or [[Stroboscope|stroboscopy]] (method depends on the type of laryngitis).<ref name=":07"/>{{rp|108}} Other features of the laryngeal tissues may include * Redness of the laryngeal tissues (acute) * Dilated blood vessels (acute) * Thick, yet dry laryngal tissue (chronic) * Stiff vocal folds * Sticky secretions between the vocal folds and nearby structures (the interarytenoid region)
=== Referral === Some signs and symptoms indicate the need for early referral.<ref name=BMJ2014/> These include * Difficulty swallowing * Vocal [[stridor]] * Ear pain * Recent weight loss * History of smoking * Current or recent radiotherapy treatment (in the neck region) * Recent neck surgery or surgery involving [[Tracheal tube|endotracheal tubing]] * Person is a professional voice user (teacher, singer, actor, call center worker, and so on)
===Differential diagnosis=== *Acute epiglottitis: This is more likely in those with [[stridor]], drooling, and painful or trouble swollowing.<ref name="BMJ2014" /> *Granulomatous laryngitis *Pseudomyxomatous laryngitis * [[Croup]]: This presents with a barking cough, [[Hoarse voice|hoarseness]] of voice, and [[Stridor|inspiratory stridor]].<ref name=":0" />
==Treatment== Treatment is often supportive in nature, and depends on the severity and type of laryngitis (acute or chronic).<ref name="BMJ2014"/> General measures to relieve symptoms of laryngitis include behaviour modification, hydration and humidification.<ref name="BMJ2014"/>
Vocal hygiene (care of the voice) is very important to relieve symptoms of laryngitis. Vocal hygiene involves measures such as: resting the voice, drinking sufficient water, reducing caffeine and alcohol intake, stopping smoking and limiting throat clearing.<ref name="BMJ2014"/>
=== Acute laryngitis === In general, acute laryngitis treatment involves vocal hygiene, painkillers ([[analgesic]]s), humidification, and antibiotics.<ref name="BMJ2014"/><ref name=Rev2015/>
==== Viral ==== The suggested treatment for viral laryngitis involves vocal rest, [[Analgesic|pain medication]], and mucolytics for frequent coughing.<ref name=":07">{{Cite book|title=Understanding Voice Problems|last=Colton|first=Raymond H.|last2=Casper|first2=Janina K.|last3=Leonard|first3=Rebecca|last4=|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|year=2011|isbn=978-1-60913-874-5|edition=4th|location=Baltimore, MD|pages=308–309|via=}}</ref> Home remedies such as tea and honey may also be helpful.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> Antibiotics are not used for treatment of viral laryngitis.<ref name="BMJ2014"/><ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Dominguez, L. M.|last2=Simpson, C. B.|date=December 2015|title=Viral laryngitis|journal=Current Opinion in Otolaryngology & Head and Neck Surgery|volume=23|issue=6|pages=454–458.|doi=10.1097/moo.0000000000000203}}</ref>
==== Bacterial ==== [[Antibiotics]] may be prescribed for bacterial laryngitis, especially when symptoms of upper respiratory infection are present.<ref name=":07"/> However, the use of antibiotics is highly debated for acute laryngitis. This relates to issues of effectiveness, side effects, cost, and possibility of antibiotic resistance patterns. Overall, antibiotics do not appear to be very effective in the treatment of acute laryngitis.<ref name=Rev2015/>
In severe cases of bacterial laryngitis, such as supraglottitis or epiglottitis, there is a higher risk of the airway becoming blocked.<ref name=":07"/> An urgent referral should be made to manage the airway.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> Treatment may involve humidification, [[corticosteroid]]s, intravenous antibiotics, and nebulised adrenaline.<ref name=":07"/>
==== Fungal ==== Fungal laryngitis can be treated with oral antifungal tablets and antifungal solutions.<ref name="BMJ2014"/><ref name=":07"/> These are typically used for up to three weeks and treatment may need to be repeated if the fungal infection returns.<ref name=":07"/>
====Trauma==== Laryngitis caused by excessive use or misuse of the voice can be managed though vocal hygiene measures.
=== Chronic laryngitis ===
==== Reflux ==== [[Laryngopharyngeal reflux]] treatment primarily involves behavioural management and medication.<ref name="BMJ2014"/><ref name=":07"/> Behavioural management involves aspects such as * Wearing loose clothing * Eating smaller, more frequent meals * Avoiding certain foods (e.g. caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods)<ref name=":07"/> Anti-reflux medications may be prescribed for patients with signs of chronic laryngitis and hoarse voice.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schwartz|first=Seth R.|last2=Cohen|first2=Seth M.|last3=Dailey|first3=Seth H.|last4=Rosenfeld|first4=Richard M.|last5=Deutsch|first5=Ellen S.|last6=Gillespie|first6=M. Boyd|last7=Granieri|first7=Evelyn|last8=Hapner|first8=Edie R.|last9=Kimball|first9=C. Eve|date=2009-09-01|title=Clinical Practice Guideline Hoarseness (Dysphonia)|url=http://oto.sagepub.com/content/141/3_suppl/S1|journal=Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery|language=en|volume=141|issue=3 suppl|pages=S1–S31|doi=10.1016/j.otohns.2009.06.744|issn=0194-5998|pmid=19729111|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709154054/http://oto.sagepub.com/content/141/3_suppl/S1|archivedate=2015-07-09|df=}}</ref> If anti-reflux treatment does not result in a decrease of symptoms, other possible causes should be examined.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> Over-the-counter medications for neutralizing acids ([[antacid]]s) and acid suppressants ([[H2 blockers|H-2 blockers]]) may be used.<ref name=":07"/> Antacids are often short-acting and may not be sufficient for treatment.<ref name=":07"/> [[Proton-pump inhibitor|Proton pump inhibitors]] are an effective type of medication.<ref name=":07"/> These should only be prescribed for a set period of time, after which the symptoms should be reviewed.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> Proton pump inhibitors do not work for everyone. A physical reflux barrier (e.g. Gaviscon Liquid) may be more appropriate for some.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> Antisecretory medications can have several side-effects.<ref name="BMJ2014"/>
When appropriate, anti-reflux surgery may benefit some individuals.<ref name="BMJ2014"/>
==== Inflammatory ==== When treating allergic laryngitis, topical nasal steroids and [[immunotherapy]] have been found to be effective for [[allergic rhinitis]].<ref name=":07"/> [[Antihistamine]]s may also be helpful, but can create a dryness in the larynx.<ref name=":07" /> Inhaled steroids that are used for a long period can lead to problems with the larynx and voice.<ref name=":07" />
==== Autoimmune ==== [[Mucous membrane pemphigoid]] may be managed with medication ([[cyclophosphamide]] and [[prednisolone]]).<ref name="BMJ2014"/>
==== Granulomatous ==== [[Sarcoidosis]] is typically treated with [[systemic corticosteroids]]. Less frequently used treatments include intralesional injections or laser resection.<ref name="BMJ2014"/>
==Prognosis==
=== Acute === Acute laryngitis may persist, but will typically resolve on its own within two weeks.<ref name="BMJ2014"/> Recovery is likely to be quick if the patient follows the treatment plan.<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Jonas|first=Nico|year=2007|title=Laryngitis Management|journal=Journal of Modern Pharmacy|volume=14|issue=5|page=44}}</ref> In viral laryngitis, symptoms can persist for an extended amount of time, even when upper respiratory tract inflammation has been resolved.<ref name=":32"/>
=== Chronic === Laryngitis that continues for more than three weeks is considered [[chronic condition|chronic]].<ref name="BMJ2014"/> If laryngeal symptoms last for more than three weeks, a referral should be made for further examination, including direct [[laryngoscopy]].<ref name="BMJ2014" /> The prognosis for chronic laryngitis varies depending on the cause of the laryngitis.<ref name=":42"/>

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Dynamic list}} [[File:John Paul II Medal of Freedom 2004.jpg|thumb|[[Pope John Paul II]] was the subject of three premature obituaries.]] <onlyinclude><!-- See [[Wikipedia talk:Featured lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below --> A '''premature obituary''' is an [[obituary]] published whose subject is not actually deceased at the time of publication. Examples of premature obituaries include that of inventor, businessman, and chemist [[Alfred Nobel]], whose premature obituary condemning him as a "merchant of death" may have caused him to create the [[Nobel Prize]];<ref name="TIME20001016">{{Cite journal | last = Golden | first = Frederic | date = October 16, 2000 | title = The Worst And The Brightest | journal = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | volume = | issue = | pages = | location = New York City, United States | issn = 0040-781X | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,998209,00.html | accessdate = March 20, 2009 }}</ref> black nationalist [[Marcus Garvey]], whose actual death was apparently caused by reading his own obituary;<ref name="20010119TAE">{{cite episode | title = Marcus Garvey: Look for Me in the Whirlwind | series = American Experience | serieslink = American Experience | network = [[Public Broadcasting Service]] | airdate = January 19, 2001 | season = 13 | number = 6 | url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/garvey/filmmore/pt.html }}</ref> and actor [[Abe Vigoda]], who was the subject of so many premature obituaries that a website was created to state whether he was alive or dead.
This article lists the recipients of incorrect death reports (not just formal [[obituary|obituaries]]) from publications, media organisations, official bodies, and widely used information sources such as the [[Internet Movie Database]]; but not mere rumours of deaths, nor reports from sites which feature automated death hoax stories designed to draw in page clicks from specific web searches. People who were presumed (though not categorically declared) to be dead, and joke death reports that were widely believed, are also included.</onlyinclude>
==Causes== Premature obituaries may be published for reasons such as the following: * '''Accidental publication''': accidental release of a pre-written obituary, usually on a news web site, as a result of technical or human error. The most egregious example was when, in 2003, [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN accidentally released]] draft obituaries for seven major world figures. * '''Brush with death''': when the subject unexpectedly survives a serious life-threatening illness or accident which made the person appear to be dead or certain to die, or, in some cases, is hours or days from their actual death due to such an illness or accident but has not actually died at the time of publication of the premature obituary. * '''Clerical errors''': due to clerical errors, almost 500 living people in the United States are inadvertently considered dead each month by the [[Social Security Administration]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/08/10/489318279/social-security-data-errors-can-turn-people-into-the-living-dead|title=Social Security Data Errors Can Turn People Into The Living Dead|newspaper=NPR.org|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> *'''[[Faked death]]''': when the subject fakes their own death in order to evade legal, financial, or marital difficulties and start a new life. * '''Fraud victim''': many people from [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]] have been registered dead by officials who are bribed by relatives who want to steal the victim's land. The ensuing legal disputes often continue for many years, with victims growing elderly and sometimes dying in reality before they are resolved (see [[Association of Dead People]]). *'''[[Death hoax|Hoax]]''': when a death is falsely reported, generally as a prank. Some websites (notably mediamass.net)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wafflesatnoon.com/mediamass-fake-news/|title=Mediamass.net: Fake News That Fooled Real News}}</ref> publish both celebrity death hoaxes and refutations of actual celebrity deaths as a form of [[clickbait]]. *'''[[Impostor]]''': when an ordinary person who for years has passed himself off to family and friends as a retired minor celebrity dies, it can prompt an erroneous obituary for the real (but still living) celebrity. * '''Misidentified body''': when a corpse is misidentified as someone else, often someone who was involved in the same incident or who happened to go missing at the same time. *'''[[Missing in action]]''': soldiers who go missing in war are sometimes incorrectly declared dead if no body is found. In particular, a number of [[Japanese holdout|Japanese soldiers]] thought to have died in World War II in fact survived – typically hiding in a remote jungle for years or even decades, believing that the war had not ended. * '''Misunderstandings''': such as when a [[Sky News]] employee thought that a rehearsal for the future death of the [[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Queen Mother]] was real. * '''Name confusion''': where someone with an identical or similar name has died. Usually the subject of the obituary is famous but the deceased person is not.
{{Compact ToC |side=yes |center=yes |align=center |nobreak=yes |custom1=The CNN.com incident |custom2=Premature obituaries in fiction |seealso=yes |refs=yes |extlinks=yes }}
==A== *'''[[Alan Abel]]''' reported his own death in a [[skiing]] accident as an elaborate hoax on New Year's Day, {{start date|1980}}, to get his obituary published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="NYP19800102">{{Cite news | first = Richard | last = Gooding | title = Author's Death Exaggerated | work = [[New York Post]] | location = New York City, United States | page = | date = January 4, 1980 }}</ref> Abel died on September 14, 2018.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/17/obituaries/alan-abel-dies.html]. ''New York Times''. Retrieved September 19, 2018.</ref> [[File:Detail Ali Hassan al-Majid.jpg|thumb|[[Ali Hassan al-Majid]] (2004)]] *'''[[Sinbad (comedian)|David Adkins]]''', known professionally as '''Sinbad''', was the subject of a death hoax. On March 14, 2007, it was reported that the comedian had died of a heart attack. He later spoke with a reporter from the [[Associated Press]] about the hoax.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/sinbad.asp | title=Sinbad Death Hoax | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Ali Hassan al-Majid]]''' was supposed dead in {{start date|2003|04}}, after British and United States officials reported that he had died in an air strike in [[Basra]]; al-Majid had been seen going into the building that was attacked, and corpses of his [[bodyguard]]s were positively identified, though there was less certainty about the identity of al-Majid's supposed corpse. After obituaries of the Iraqi general, politician and first-cousin of [[Saddam Hussein]] were published in many newspapers, reports then circulated that he had escaped by boat, and subsequently been seen joking with staff in a hospital in [[Baghdad]]. Al-Majid was captured several months later, and sentenced to death in 2007 for war crimes.<ref name="Telegraph20030821">{{Cite news |first=Robin |last=Gedye |title='Chemical Ali' outlived death reports |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2003/08/22/wirq122.xml&sSheet=/news/2003/08/22/ixnewstop.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London, England |date=August 21, 2003 |accessdate=March 22, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104064750/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2003%2F08%2F22%2Fwirq122.xml&sSheet=%2Fnews%2F2003%2F08%2F22%2Fixnewstop.html |archivedate=November 4, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He was hanged on January 25, 2010. *'''[[John Allen (murderer)|John Allen]]''', a serial criminal, faked his own suicide by drowning off [[Beachy Head]] (Britain's most notorious suicide spot) in 1966 to escape prosecution for [[theft]], presumably resulting in his being declared dead. He in fact swam around the coast, retrieved dry clothes that he had hidden, and took up a new identity. However, his crimes continued, including further thefts and [[bigamy]]. In 2002 he was jailed for life for having murdered his wife and children in 1975. He died in 2015.<ref name="Independent20021217">{{Cite news | first = Jason | last = Bennetto | title = Bigamist sentenced to life for murdering wife and children who disappeared 27 years ago | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/bigamist-sentenced-to-life-for-murdering-wife-and-children-who-disappeared-27-years-ago-611230.html | work = [[The Independent]] | location = [[Canary Wharf]], London, England | date = December 17, 2002 | accessdate = March 22, 2009 }}</ref> *'''[[Rex Alston]]''', a retired BBC sports commentator, garnered the unusual distinction of having his marriage announced in ''[[The Times]]'' after his obituary when that paper updated the sportsman's internal obituary file and accidentally published it in 1985. Alston, who was 84 at the time, lived for another nine years until his actual death in 1994 at the age of 93.<ref name="Wisden1995p1378">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] | year = 1995 | publisher = John Wisden & Co | pages = 1378 }}</ref>
* '''[[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi#Reports of death, bodily harm, and arrest|Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]]''' terrorist leader of [[ISIL]] has been reported dead, injured or arrested numerous times over a number of years by various governments, in media, and on Wikipedia.
==B== * '''[[Arkady Babchenko]]''', a Russian journalist living in Ukraine was widely reported on 29 May 2018, to have been shot dead.<ref>{{cite web |title=Russia's opposition journalist Arkady Babchenko shot dead in Kiev |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-44296672 |website=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=30 May 2018}}</ref> A day later, Babchenko appeared at a press conference with the [[Security Service of Ukraine]], claiming to have staged his death to expose Russian agents.<ref>{{cite web |title='Murdered' Russian journalist Arkady Babchenko is alive |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-44307611 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=30 May 2018}}</ref> * '''[[Lawrence Joseph Bader]],''' an [[Akron, Ohio|Akron]], Ohio, kitchenware salesman who faked death by drowning. On May 15, 1957, he left his wife Marylou (five months pregnant) their three kids, and five years of unpaid income taxes, sailing out on [[Lake Erie]], and vanished (right after increasing his life insurance policy). His boat was found abandoned, and the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] announced that no one could have survived. In 1960, he was pronounced dead. He turned up in [[Omaha, Nebraska]] under the alias of John Francis Johnson, a TV personality, married. He was found by his 21 year old niece, and caught when his fingerprints matched those of Lawrence Bader. Bader died in 1966.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1734&dat=19650210&id=C00fAAAAIBAJ&pg=6932,2562925|title=The Dispatch – Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|access-date=December 15, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Inc1965">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KkEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA41|title=LIFE|date=March 5, 1965|publisher=Time Inc|pages=41–44|issn=0024-3019|author=Time Inc}}</ref> * '''William Baer''', a [[New York University]] professor, was declared dead by his ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' obituary in May 1942 as a hoax by his students.<ref name="NYT19420509">{{Cite news | title = DR. WILLIAM BAER, DEAN AT N. Y. O., 37 | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50B1FFA3E58167B93CBA9178ED85F468485F9 | work = [[The New York Times]] | issn = 0362-4331 | date = May 9, 1942 | accessdate = April 23, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="MOHWilliamBaer">{{cite web | title = The Death of Lou Reed | url = http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/day/05_09_2001.html | work = [[Museum of Hoaxes]] | publisher = Alex Boese | location = [[San Diego]], [[California]], USA | date = May 9, 2001 }}</ref>[[File:Luca Barbareschi.jpg|thumb|Luca Barbareschi.]] *'''[[Scott Baio]]''': A hoax report circulated via e-mail claimed that this American actor had died in a car accident on December 18, 1997. The report was picked up by some media outlets, even causing several members of Baio's family to briefly believe he was dead.<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=voIe7XkFvEsC&pg=PA114|title=Truth and Rumors: The Reality Behind TV's Most Famous Myths|first=Bill|last=Brioux|date=April 23, 2018|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|accessdate=April 23, 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> *'''[[Luca Barbareschi]]''' was one of four actors whom the Italian police believed had been murdered while making the 1980 horror film ''[[Cannibal Holocaust]]''. The film was so realistic that shortly after it was released its director, [[Ruggero Deodato]], was arrested for murder. The actors had signed contracts to stay out of the media for a year in order to fuel rumours that the film was a [[snuff film]], and the court was only convinced they were alive when the contracts were cancelled and the actors appeared on a television show as proof.<ref name="In the Jungle">{{cite video |people = Ruggero Deodato (interviewee) |date = 2003 |title = In the Jungle: The Making of Cannibal Holocaust |medium = [[Documentary film]] |publisher = Alan Young Pictures |location = Italy |accessdate = |time = }}</ref><ref name="Interview 2">{{cite interview | last = Deodato | first = Ruggero | subjectlink = Ruggero Deodato | interviewer = [[Sage Stallone]]; [[Bob Murawski]] | title = Cult-Con 2000 | type = | work = Cannibal Holocaust DVD Commentary | location = [[Tarrytown, New York]], USA | date = November 12, 2000 | accessdate = }}</ref> *'''[[Sabine Baring-Gould]]''', English author, had his obituary published in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on June 5, 1906;<ref name="NYT19060605">{{cite news | date = June 5, 1906 | title = Rev. S. Baring-Gould Dead | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/06/05/101843569.pdf | newspaper = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | issn = 0362-4331 | oclc = 1645522 }}</ref> Baring-Gould died in 1924. *'''[[Mandela Barnes]]''', a former member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] and the [[Democratic Party of Wisconsin|Democratic]] nominee for [[Lieutenant Governor of Wisconsin]] in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2018|the 2018 election for governor and lieutenant governor in Wisconsin]], was erroneously reported as having been killed in a motorcycle crash north of [[Milwaukee]]. The error was caused by a photo of Barnes incorrectly being broadcast by [[WDJT-TV|the CBS affiliate in Milwaukee]] during a local news report about a different person being killed in a motorcycle crash.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stanley-Baker |first1=Issac |title=The news was wrong: Mandela Barnes is alive, not dead. He's black, not white. And he just claimed a victory in Wisconsin. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/08/16/the-reports-are-wrong-mandela-barnes-is-alive-hes-black-and-he-just-scored-a-victory-in-a-wisconsin-election/ |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=20 August 2018}}</ref> *'''[[P.T. Barnum]]''''s premature obituary was published, unusually, not because of deception or error, but sympathy. When he took to his deathbed, Barnum expressed the wish that he might read what the papers would say about him. The ''[[New York Sun|New York Evening Sun]]'' obligingly printed his obituary on March 24, 1891, two weeks before his actual death on April 7. The newspaper acknowledged to its readers that Barnum was still alive at the time of publication.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Saxon|first1=A. H.|title=P.T. Barnum: The Legend and the Man|date=1989|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780231056878|page=326|edition=rev.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HsEHOkSK8HAC&lpg=PA326|accessdate=June 30, 2015}}</ref> *'''[[Edward Bartlett (cricketer)|Edward Bartlett]]''' was reported in the 1934 edition of ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'' to have died "about February" the previous year. In fact, he lived until December 21, 1976.<ref name="Wisden1934p259">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] | year = 1934 | publisher = John Wisden & Co | pages = 259 }}</ref> *'''[[John Basedow]]''' was reported by [[PRWeb]] to have died in Thailand due to the [[tsunami]] resulting from the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]]; the story was quickly retracted.<ref name="ABCnews20060327">{{Cite news | title = Will Ferrell Lives: Dead Wrong Death Rumors | first = Buck | last = Wolf | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/WolfFiles/Story?id=1805147&page=1 | publisher = [[ABC News]] | location = United States | date = March 27, 2006 | accessdate = September 23, 2009 | quote = In Other News, Paul McCartney and the Taco Bell Chihuahua Are Still Alive and Kicking }}</ref> *'''[[Charles Baudelaire]]''', a French poet, was reported to have died by Paris newspapers in April 1866, after suffering a massive stroke while in Belgium.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Judgment of Paris: The Revolutionary Decade That Gave The World Impressionism |author-first=Ross |author-last=King |author-link=Ross King (author) |publisher=[[Walker & Company]] |date=2006 |page=198 |isbn=0-8027-1466-8}}</ref> Although the obituaries were incorrect at the time, he died soon after, on August 31, 1867. *'''[[Beyoncé]]''': On February 23, 2015, a fake news report surfaced on Twitter claiming that the singer was killed in a car crash. The report caused the hashtag #RIPBeyonce to become trending on Twitter, even though she is still living.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/beyonce.asp | title=Beyoncé Knowles Death Hoax | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 25, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Mayim Bialik]]''': according to the 2008 book ''Truth and Rumors: The Reality Behind TV's Most Famous Myths'', Bialik was once the subject of a premature obituary. However, no further details are given.<ref name="books.google.com"/> *'''[[Lal Bihari]]''' is the Indian founder of the [[Uttar Pradesh Association of Dead People]], an organisation which highlights the plight of people in [[Uttar Pradesh]] who are incorrectly declared dead by relatives in order to steal their land, usually in collusion with corrupt officials. Bihari himself was officially dead from 1976 to 1994 as a result of his uncle's attempt to acquire his land. Among various attempts to publicize his situation and demonstrate that he was alive, he stood for election against [[Rajiv Gandhi]] in 1989 (and lost). He was awarded the [[Ig Nobel Prize|Ig Nobel Peace Prize]] in 2003 for his 'posthumous' activities.<ref name="time.com">{{cite journal |last1 = Fathers |first1 = Michael |date = July 19, 1999 |title = Plight of the Living Dead |url = http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2054133,00.html |journal = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |location = New York City |issn = 0040-781X |oclc = 1311479 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6OCcsIvDN?url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2054133,00.html |archivedate = March 20, 2014 |accessdate = March 19, 2014 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref><ref name="Khaleej20070423">{{cite news | date = April 23, 2007 | newspaper = [[Khaleej Times]] }}</ref> *'''[[Jack Black]]'''. On June 4, 2016, the Twitter page of Black's band [[Tenacious D]] announced the actor and musician's death. However, the next day both Black and bandmate [[Kyle Gass]] clarified that the page was hacked and that Black was alive and well.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.snopes.com/jack-black-death-hoax/|title=FALSE: Jack Black Dead|last=Evon|first=Dan|newspaper=snopes|access-date=February 7, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> * '''Paul Blais''', a [[United States Air Force|US Air Force]] [[senior airman]], was listed as one of 19 people believed killed in the 1996 [[Khobar Towers bombing]]. However, it transpired that he was alive, though in a coma, having been confused with another airman who had died.<ref name="CNN19960629">{{cite news |date=June 29, 1996 |title=For a mother, mourning turns into celebration |url=http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9606/29/saudi.alive/ |publisher=CNN |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OCdXY9sG?url=http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9606/29/saudi.alive/ |archivedate=March 20, 2014 |accessdate=March 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *'''[[Lucien Bouchard]]''': the former [[Quebec]] premier (who had been seriously ill) was reported dead by [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] in September 2005. The network began broadcasting a live tribute to the politician, but cut it short with a sheepish confirmation that he was in fact alive, blaming [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|Radio-Canada]] for the error. CTV and Radio-Canada continued to blame each other thereafter.<ref>[http://www.regrettheerror.com/television/networks-argue-over-false-death-report "Networks argue over false death report"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031160257/http://www.regrettheerror.com/television/networks-argue-over-false-death-report/ |date=October 31, 2007 }}, RegretTheError.com, September 9, 2005.</ref> *'''[[Peter Boyle]]''', TV and movie character actor, was briefly and incorrectly declared deceased in October 1990, a few weeks following a massive stroke where he was almost paralyzed and could not move or speak for nearly six months. His incorrect lifespan of 1933–1990 is listed in the book ''Cult Movie Stars'' by author Danny Peary.<ref>{{cite book |first=Danny |last=Peary |title=Cult Movie Stars |ISBN=0-671-74924-2}}</ref> Boyle made a complete recovery from the blood clot in his brain and continued acting despite multiple and persistent health problems, including high blood pressure. He had another brush with death in 1999 when he suffered a heart attack while working on the set of the sitcom ''[[Everybody Loves Raymond]]'', but he again recovered and was working again within one week. Boyle died on December 12, 2006. *'''[[James Brady]]''', White House Press Secretary, was shot in the head in the 1981 [[Reagan assassination attempt|assassination attempt]] on President [[Ronald Reagan]]. Three hours later, amid confusion about the extent of his injuries, all three U.S. broadcast TV networks erroneously announced that Brady had died,<ref>{{Cite book|last=Abrams|first=Herbert L.|title=The President Has Been Shot |publisher=Norton|year=1992|page=125}}</ref> triggering an on-air outburst by [[ABC News]] anchor [[Frank Reynolds]] when the information was revealed incorrect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/freynold.htm|title=Frank Reynolds: Sergeant, United States Army – Journalist|publisher=[[Arlington National Cemetery]]|accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> This led to greater subsequent caution about issuing death reports during rapidly developing situations.<ref name="Castro, J.: The Pope's been shot!">[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,924769-1,00.html Castro, J.: "The Pope's been shot!"], ''[[TIME]]'' magazine, May 25, 1981.</ref> Brady died on August 4, 2014. *'''Adam Buckley''': The resident of [[Santa Clarita, California]], who had [[schizophrenia]], went missing in June 2018. On July 2, a burned body was found in [[Lancaster, California|Lancaster]], and the Los Angeles County Coroner misidentified the body as being Buckley's. In late August, the Coroner released a statement saying that they had misidentified the body, and Buckley was found alive on September 14.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2018/09/01/i-was-horrified-mother-falsely-told-son-was-dead-by-la-coroner-still-searching-for-his-whereabouts/|title='I Was Horrified:' Mother Falsely Told Son Was Dead By LA Coroner Still Searching For His Whereabouts|date=2018-09-01|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2018/09/14/la-man-misidentified-as-dead-found-safe/|title=Missing Man Who Was Misidentified By LA Coroner As Dead Found Safe|date=2018-09-14|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en}}</ref> *'''[[Rodger Bumpass]]''' (voice actor), reported in August 2006 to have died during heart surgery, by [[Jonesboro, Arkansas]] station [[KAIT]], the [[Internet Movie Database]], and [[Arkansas State University]]'s newsletter.<ref>[http://www.kait8.com/Global/story.asp?S=5335667 "Reports of death of Squidward's "voice" premature] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927005135/http://www.kait8.com/Global/story.asp?S=5335667 |date=September 27, 2007 }}, Kait8.com, August 28, 2006.</ref> *'''John Burney''': Shortly after the collapse of his business, this resident of [[Helena, Arkansas]] disappeared on June 11, 1976. He was eventually declared dead, which allowed both his wife and his company to receive life insurance benefits. However, Burney resurfaced in December 1982 when he visited his father who had recently been injured in an accident. In the intervening years, Burney had taken up residence in [[Key Largo, Florida]] under the name John Bruce and had married a second wife without ever divorcing his first one. He was eventually convicted of fraud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/2253/what-happens-when-someone-legally-dead-shows-up-alive|title=What happens when someone "legally dead" shows up alive?|date=June 13, 2006|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Pat Burns]],''' a NHL coach was reported to have died from cancer on September 17, 2010, by the ''Toronto Star''. He actually died two months later on November 19. *'''[[Steve Burns]]''', host of children's show ''[[Blues Clues]]'', was rumored to have died from a drug overdose in 1998; others claimed that Burns was struck and killed by a car.
