Burns went on ''[[The Rosie O'Donnell Show]]'' to debunk those rumors.<ref>Mikkelson, Barbara, "Demise and Shine: Steve of ''Blues Clues'' died of a heroin overdose'', [[Snopes.com]], August 5, 2007.[http://www.snopes.com/radiotv/tv/bluesclues.asp] Retrieved December 20, 2013''</ref> *'''[[Barbara Bush]]''', former [[First Lady of the United States]], had a draft obituary (conspicuously marked "DO NOT PUBLISH") leaked by [[CBSNews.com]] on April 15, 2018, after her family announced that she was in failing health and ending further medical treatment.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sweeney |first1=Don |title=CBS erroneously publishes obituary for former first lady Barbara Bush |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article208965104.html |website=[[The Miami Herald|MiamiHerald.com]] |accessdate=April 15, 2018 |date=April 15, 2018}}</ref> The following day, a [[fake news]] Web site pretending to be [[CNN.com]] falsely claimed Bush had died.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3469247-fake-news-former-first-lady-barbara-bush-dies-at-92---cnn.html|title=Fake News: Former First Lady Barbara Bush Did NOT Die At 92 (UPDATE: She Did Now) – Lead Stories|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> Bush died one day after that on April 17. *'''[[George H. W. Bush]]''' was erroneously reported dead in an e-mail by [[WBAP (AM)|WBAP-AM]]/[[KTCK-FM|WBAP-FM]], due to a false tip. At the time, Bush was in intensive care recovering from illness.<ref>Nicholson, Eric (December 28, 2012). [http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/unfairpark/2012/12/wbap_announces_death_of_george.php WBAP announces death of George H. W. Bush, quickly realizes he's not actually dead]. ''Dallas Observer''. Retrieved December 28, 2012.</ref> The German magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' erroneously published a draft obituary for Bush on December 30, 2012, during his recovery from the same illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/german-magazine-mistakenly-publishes-bush-obituary-132006952.html|title=German magazine mistakenly publishes Bush obituary|date=December 30, 2012|work=Yahoo! News}}</ref> Bush had previously been the subject of another near-miss while President, when [[HLN (TV channel)|CNN Headline News]] almost reported a false tip stating Bush had died.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-01-10/entertainment/ca-1610_1_cnn-s-headline-news|title=CNN Averts Hoax About Bush's 'Death'|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=McDougal|first=Dennis|date=January 10, 1992}}</ref> Another death hoax circulated in July 2014, when it was reported that Bush had died from food poisoning.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/georgehwbush.asp | title=George H.W. Bush Death Hoax | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> Bush died on November 30, 2018. * Either George H. W. Bush or '''[[George W. Bush]]''', when the moving banner headline on South African television's ETV News read "George Bush is dead". A technician who was testing the banner accidentally pressed the "broadcast live for transmission" button, according to the BBC.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7880832.stm |title=SA TV make 'Bush dead' |date=February 11, 2009 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref> George H. W. Bush died on November 30, 2018.
==C== [[File:Fidel Castro.jpg|thumb|[[Fidel Castro]], inaccurately described by [[CNN]] as "lifeguard, athlete, movie star".]]
* '''Janelle Cahoon''': in December 2005, the ''[[Duluth News Tribune]]'' claimed that the [[Benedictine]] [[nun]]'s funeral had been shown in a 1999 documentary. The mistake caused much amusement at her monastery, with some sisters asking her what heaven was like, and others referring to the incident as "Dead Nun Walking".<ref>[http://www.regrettheerror.com/2005/12/paper_kills_nun.html "Paper kills nun"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021063228/http://www.regrettheerror.com/2005/12/paper_kills_nun.html |date=October 21, 2006 }}, RegretTheError.com, December 27, 2005.</ref> *'''[[Mark Calaway]]''' ([[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] better known as The Undertaker): On April 17, 2014, rumors claimed that Callaway was found dead in his New Mexico home.<ref name="Hoax slayer"/> * '''Carlos Camejo''', a Venezuelan man declared dead in September 2007 after a traffic accident, revived during his autopsy. After making an incision in his face, examiners realized something was wrong when he started bleeding. "I woke up because the pain was unbearable", Camejo said.<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUKN149975820070914?feedType=RSS&feedName=oddlyEnoughNews "'Dead' man wakes up under autopsy knife"], [[Reuters]], September 14, 2007.</ref> * '''Graham Cardwell''', a [[Lincolnshire]] dockmaster who disappeared in September 1998 and was assumed drowned. Eight months later he was discovered living in secret in the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]]. He claimed he had thought he was suffering from cancer (though had not sought medical attention) and wanted to spare his family the trauma of it.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/364379.stm "'Reggie Perrin' father escapes punishment"], [[BBC]] News web site, June 8, 1999.</ref> * '''[[David Cameron]],''' the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, when [[David Bowie]]'s death was announced in January 2016, a newsreader on [[Heart (radio network)|Heart Radio]] Scotland accidentally announced that David Cameron had died.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jan/11/radio-presenter-david-cameron-david-bowie|title=Radio presenter announces David Cameron's death instead of David Bowie|first=Mark|last=Sweney|date=January 11, 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> * '''Feliberto Carrasco''': this 81-year-old Chilean man woke up in his coffin at his own wake in January 2008. His family had found his body lying limp and cold, and assumed he must have died. While he was lying in his coffin, dressed in a suit and surrounded by relatives, his nephew saw him wake up, though did not believe it at first. Carrasco said he was not in any pain, and asked for a glass of water. His death had been announced on a local radio station, which issued a correction.<ref>[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gNcmRrvq5AKUtY4m0N-OAkL1McFg "Not dead yet, Chilean man wakes up at his own wake"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127125715/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gNcmRrvq5AKUtY4m0N-OAkL1McFg |date=January 27, 2008 }}, [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]], January 20, 2008.</ref> *'''[[Fidel Castro]]:''' the former leader of Cuba was reported dead in the [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN.com incident]]. The draft obituary, which had used [[Ronald Reagan]]'s as a template, described Castro as 'lifeguard, athlete, movie star'. Castro died on November 25, 2016. *'''[[Whitney Cerak]]:''' a student was thought to have died in April 2006 when a van from [[Taylor University]] collided with a tractor trailer, leaving five dead. 1400 people attended her funeral. Fellow student Laura VanRyn was thought to have survived the accident, which left her in a coma and heavily bandaged. Suspicions were only aroused when during her gradual recovery in the hospital, VanRyn started making strange comments and using names wrongly; her university roommate also reported that she did not appear to be VanRyn. Weeks after the accident, when concerned hospital staff asked her her name, she wrote 'Whitney Cerak', which was confirmed by dental records. The tragic mix-up appeared to have been caused by Cerak's and VanRyn's somewhat similar appearance, and confusion at the crash scene.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-05-31-indiana-mistaken-identity_x.htm Kim, T.: "Case of mistaken identity stuns families"], ''[[USA Today]]'', May 31, 2006.</ref><ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-06-04-mistakenID_x.htm "Mistaken identities: Confusion of horrific accident resulted in wrong tag"], ''[[USA Today]]'', June 3, 2006.</ref> Cerak co-wrote a book about her experience titled ''Mistaken Identity: Two Families, One Survivor, Unwavering Hope''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1416567356|title=Mistaken Identity: Two Families, One Survivor, Unwavering Hope|first1=Don & Susie Van|last1=Ryn|first2=Newell Colleen & Whitney|last2=Cerak|first3=Mark|last3=Tabb|date=March 25, 2008|publisher=Howard Books|accessdate=April 23, 2018|via=Amazon}}</ref> *'''[[Joshua Chamberlain]]:''' an [[American Civil War]] officer and [[Governor of Maine]] was shot through the hip and groin in the 1864 [[Siege of Petersburg]], he was thought to be on the point of death, and so was reported dead by at least one newspaper (perhaps ''[[The New York Times]]''). However, he gradually recovered in hospital. Chamberlain was shown the newspaper report 'when they thought he was able to take it', and reportedly 'got a great kick out of seeing his obituary'.<ref>[http://community.curtislibrary.com/pejepscot/csmith.htm "Interview between Mrs. Paul Copeland and Mrs. Winfield Smith on General Chamberlain"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114221544/http://community.curtislibrary.com/pejepscot/csmith.htm |date=November 14, 2007 }}, Pejepscot Historical Society, 1970s.</ref> He died in 1914.<ref>[[Joshua Chamberlain]]</ref> *'''[[Jackie Chan]]''': On June 20, 2013, a false report claimed that the actor had been killed in an accident while filming a movie in [[Austria]]. Another hoax article that surfaced in September of that year had also reported the same thing.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/austriadeath.asp | title=Jackie Chan Death Hoax | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Jan Chapman]]''': The 'In Memoriam' segment of the [[89th Academy Awards]], on February 26, 2017, included [[Janet Patterson]], a costume designer who died in 2016. However, the segment used a photo of Chapman instead, resulting in friends and family believing that she was dead.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/02/oscars-in-memoriam-mistake-jan-chapman-alive-janet-patterson-1201788106/|title=Oscars In Memoriam Snafu: Photo Used of Producer Who Is Still Alive {{!}} IndieWire|last=Nguyen|first=Hanh|website=www.indiewire.com|language=en|access-date=August 24, 2017}}</ref> *'''[[Chevy Chase]]:''' on January 5, 2016, ''Breaking 13 News'' published a story saying that the actor had died on January 4, 2016. The theory was quickly disproven.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.snopes.com/chevy-chase-death-hoax/|title=Chevy Chase Death Hoax|last=Evon|first=Dan|date=|work=|newspaper=Snopes|language=en-US|access-date=January 18, 2017|via=}}</ref> *'''[[Dick Cheney]]:''' The former [[Vice President of the United States]] in the [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN.com incident]]. The draft obituary, which had been based on the Queen Mother's, described Cheney as 'Queen Consort' and the 'UK's favorite grandmother'. *'''[[Francesca Ciardi]]''': see [[#B|Luca Barbareschi]] *'''[[Arthur C. Clarke]]:''' [[science fiction]] writer, had his obituary published by the G.R.A.A. (Goddard Retirees and Alumni Association) newsletter in April 2000. The obituary says he died on February 10, 2000, and even specifies the cause of death as [[interstitial lung disease|pulmonary fibrosis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://graa.gsfc.nasa.gov/newsletter/apr2000.htm|title=G|publisher=}}</ref> To date, no correction seems to have been published. Clarke died in 2008 of "respiratory complications and heart failure".<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7304004.stm | work=BBC News | title=Writer Arthur C Clarke dies at 90 | date=March 19, 2008 | accessdate=May 8, 2010}}</ref> *'''Michael Cleveland''': In October 2014, this 46-year-old man was taken to a hospital near [[Buffalo, New York]] after suffering a heart attack. A doctor declared him dead, but according to his wife he was clearly still breathing and responsive. Almost two hours passed before the doctor finally acknowledged that Cleveland was alive, and he died later that morning. {{as of|2015|October}}, Cleveland's wife is involved in a lawsuit against the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2015/10/13/husband-declared-dead-twice-wife-sues/73909434/|title=Husband declared dead twice; wife sues|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Hillary Clinton]]''': On September 11, 2016, [[WABC-TV]] television news reported that the American politician had died.<ref>McFayden, Siodhan. Whoops! News anchor accidentally announces Hillary Clinton is dead after 9/11 collapse. ''Express'' http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/710367/Whoops-News-anchor-accidentally-announces-Hillary-Clinton-is-dead-after-9-11-collapse Retrieved September 14, 2016.</ref> *'''[[Kurt Cobain]]''': The rock musician was reported dead by [[CNN]] (though he was in fact in a coma) after an overdose in Rome in March 1994, shortly before his actual [[Death of Kurt Cobain|death]] in April.<ref>[http://www.jesuismort.com/biographie_celebrite_chercher/biographie-kurt_cobain-1259.php Je Suis Mort web site (in French)] (retrieved February 12, 2007)</ref> *'''[[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]''': In 1816 the writer heard his death mentioned in a hotel by a man reading out a newspaper report of a coroner's inquest. He asked to see the paper, and was told that "it was very extraordinary that Coleridge the poet should have hanged himself just after the success of his play [''Remorse'']; but he was always a strange mad fellow". Coleridge replied: "Indeed, sir, it is a ''most extraordinary'' thing that he should have hanged himself, be the subject of an inquest, and yet that he should at this moment be speaking to you." A man had been cut down from a tree in Hyde Park, and the only identification was that his shirt was marked 'S. T. Coleridge'; Coleridge thought the shirt had probably been stolen from him.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/autobiographica00leslgoog#page/n103/ C. R. Leslie: ''Autobiographical Recollections'' (1860), pg. 34]</ref> Coleridge died in 1834.<ref>[[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]</ref> *'''[[Jeffrey Combs]]''' (actor): was confused with a businessman named Jeffrey ''Coombs'' who was aboard hijacked [[American Airlines Flight 11]], which crashed into the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] during the [[September 11 attacks]]. Combs the actor was pronounced dead by news media outlets and had to announce publicly that he was still alive. *'''[[Sean Connery]]''' (actor): in an October 25, 1993 appearance on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', Connery described recent reports of his death as a result of confusion over the then-recent death of former [[Texas]] governor [[John Connally]] as well as rumours that Connery had recently undergone treatment for [[throat cancer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0628080/|title="Late Show with David Letterman" Episode dated 25 October 1993 (TV Episode 1993)|work=IMDb}}</ref> *'''[[Alice Cooper]]''': in the early 1970s, ''[[Melody Maker]]'' magazine confused readers by publishing a satirical concert review of the rock musician in the form of a mock obituary. So many fans took it literally that Cooper had to issue a statement, reassuring them: "I'm alive, and drunk as usual."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2009/07/03/worst-celebrity-death-hoaxes.html|title=Worst Celebrity Death Hoaxes|last=Harrington|first=Amy|date=July 3, 2009|newspaper=Fox News|access-date=February 7, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> *'''[[Stephanie Courtney]]''': The actress who plays [[Flo (Progressive)|Flo]] in commercials by [[Progressive Corporation|Progressive Insurance]] was the subject of a death hoax. On May 27, 2014, it was falsely reported that she had been killed in a car crash.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/flodead.asp | title=Stephanie Courtney Death Hoax | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> <!-- *'''[[Alexander Coyle]]''': the musician and Brooklyn-based arsonist was reported dead by The Village Voice after an alleged fire-jugging incident in Omaha in December 2008. Mr. Coyle killed himself directly after hearing the news so as to be consistent.<ref>(sounds like a bad joke; if true, please cite source) --> *'''[[Ion Creangă]]''': around 1884 he suffered a severe stroke and people thought he had died. Reading his obituaries in the newspapers, Creangă reportedly said: "If this was to be the mourning I would have gotten after my death, I'm happy I haven't died yet, and so help God, may I die when people will care less about someone like me". He lived five more years, dying on December 31, 1889.<ref>Călinescu, George, ''Viaţa şi opera lui Ion Creangă (Life and works of Ion Creangă)'', Editura Litera, Chişinău, 1998, {{ISBN|9975740294}}, p. 215.</ref> *'''[[Russell Crowe]]''': the actor was reported as dead on a [[WHTZ|Z-100]] broadcast in New York City on June 10, 2010; this was later disproven by a representative for the actor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/moviestvmusic/news/rep-russell-crowe-is-not-dead-2010106|title=Rep: Russell Crowe Is Not Dead|date=June 10, 2010|work=usmagazine.com}}</ref> *'''[[Johan Cruyff]]:''' widely considered one of the best Dutch football players ever, his death was falsely reported in August 2014 when [[De Volkskrant]] accidentally uploaded a test version of their mobile website.<ref>[http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2694/Tech-Media/article/detail/3721107/2014/08/19/Foutief-bericht-over-Johan-Cruijff-in-Volkskrant-app.dhtml Volkskrant.nl – Foutief bericht over Johan Cruijff in Volkskrant-app] {{nl icon}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819134043/http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2694/Tech-Media/article/detail/3721107/2014/08/19/Foutief-bericht-over-Johan-Cruijff-in-Volkskrant-app.dhtml |date=August 19, 2014 }}</ref> He died on March 24, 2016, aged 68. * '''Delimar Vera Cuevas''': this new-born girl was declared by police to have died in a Philadelphia house fire in 1997. Six years later her mother became suspicious when a girl at a birthday party she was attending bore similarities to her other children. Subsequent DNA tests proved the girl was Delimar. Local resident Carolyn Correa is thought to have started the fire in order to kidnap her. Police could not explain why they had originally declared Delimar dead, as no human remains had been found in the fire, which had not been intense enough to completely destroy a body.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2004/US/Northeast/03/01/girl.found.alive/ "Mom finds kidnapped daughter six years later"], [[CNN.com]], March 2, 2004.</ref> *'''[[Macaulay Culkin]]''': In November 2014, a report circulated on the internet stating that the actor had been found dead in his New York City apartment. Culkin debunked the report by posting pictures of himself on Twitter, even poking fun at the hoax by writing a caption about "the great things you can do when you're alive".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/macaulay-culkin-poses-dead-death-hoax-article-1.2004595|title=Macaulay Culkin poses like he's dead after death hoax|work=NY Daily News}}</ref> *'''[[Miley Cyrus]]''': On September 5, 2008, a false [[Reuters]] article spread around the web claiming that the singer and entertainer had died in a terrible car accident. This incident, which was also reported by [[TMZ.com|TMZ]], was quickly debunked, as Miley performed in concert the following Friday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://urbanlegends.about.com/b/2008/09/06/false-rumors-claim-miley-cyrus-is-dead.htm|title=False Rumors Claim Miley Cyrus Dead|author=David Emery|work=About.com Entertainment}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/mileycyrus.asp|title=snopes.com: Miley Cyrus Death Hoax|work=snopes.com}}</ref> A similar incident took place on November 16, 2008, when someone hacked into Cyrus' [[YouTube]] account and posted a video stating she died after being hit by a drunk driver.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,24662520-5001021,00.html Sick hacker claims Miley Cyrus is dead on her YouTube account] ''The Daily Telegraph.'' Retrieved on November 16, 2008.</ref> On September 3, 2013, messages began circulating on Facebook claiming that Miley Cyrus had committed suicide due to "traumatic stress".<ref name="Hoax slayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoax-slayer.com/death-hoaxes.shtml|title=Death Hoaxes – Celebrity Death Rumours|publisher=}}</ref>
==D== *'''[[Aden Abdullah Osman Daar]]''': in May 2007 the first President of Somalia was erroneously reported dead by news portal SomaliNet and other web sites. In reality, he was in a critical condition and on life support in a Nairobi hospital following a long illness. One source said Daar's daughter had 'assumed' he had died and had informed government officials; another blamed Nairobi medical sources. Daar died shortly afterwards on June 8, 2007.<ref>[http://somalinet.com/news/world/Somalia/10580 Farah, M.A.: "Somalia: Former president in coma (correction)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070526054533/http://somalinet.com/news/world/Somalia/10580 |date=May 26, 2007 }}, SomaliNet, May 22, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200705220976.html Yusuf, A.O.: "Somalia: First President Dies At the Age of 99"], allAfrica.com, May 22, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://english.cri.cn/2947/2007/05/23/198@230282.htm "Somalia's Founding Father Dies at Age 99"], CRI English, May 23, 2007.</ref> * '''[[John Darwin disappearance case|John Darwin]]''': this British prison officer was presumed to have drowned in March 2002 when he disappeared while canoeing in the sea near [[Hartlepool]]. Despite a huge search operation, and the calm weather, only his paddle was found, followed weeks later by the wreckage of his canoe. An inquest declared him dead. However, in December 2007, Darwin walked into a London police station, announcing: "I think I'm a missing person", and claiming to have no memory of the past five years. Darwin's wife Anne, who had claimed his life insurance, says he turned up at their home in 2003 and lived in secret there and next door for three years. They also spent time together in Panama, where they planned to set up a hotel for canoeing holidays; she emigrated there shortly before Darwin reappeared. Both Darwin and his wife were subsequently convicted and imprisoned.<ref>See references in [[John Darwin disappearance case]].</ref> *'''[[Calvin Demarest]]''': The pool player was incorrectly reported dead in an insane asylum in 1916 by ''[[The New York Times]]'', which quickly retracted the claim, saying they had no idea how the error occurred.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990CE2D9103FE233A25757C2A9649C946796D6CF|title=Terse News of Sports in Town and Out|date=February 24, 1916|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=February 7, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Demarest actually died in 1925. * '''Thomas Dennison''': after this 37-year-old Briton went missing in October 2007, a body that was found in [[Greater Manchester]] was identified by his parents and caseworker as his. After the funeral and cremation, police contacted Dennison's mother, saying they thought they had in fact found him alive and living rough in [[Nottingham]] some days earlier. To prove it, they asked her for three questions only Dennison would know the answer to; he subsequently phoned her, saying "You've buried me". The body bore an uncanny resemblance to Dennison – even with similar scars and leg ulcers – leading police to ask whether he had had a twin brother.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article2795174.ece Jenkins, R.: "Missing son is found alive after mother's ordeal at cremation"], ''[[The Times]]'', November 2, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7075094.stm "'Cremated son' later found alive"], [[BBC News]], November 2, 2007.</ref> *'''[[Bob Denver]]''': In the early 1960s, this American actor was reported to have died after being electrocuted when a radio fell into his bathtub. The false report apparently began as a rumor which was picked up by several media outlets. Denver later said in an interview that for years after this incident, he would often encounter people who were surprised to see him alive. Denver actually died in 2005 of complications from throat cancer.<ref name="books.google.com"/> [[File:RIPFatsYouWillBeMissedLow9.jpg|thumb|Graffiti on [[Fats Domino]]'s home from his rumored death during Hurricane Katrina.]] *'''[[William Grenfell, 1st Baron Desborough|Lord Desborough]]:''' In 1920, ''[[The Times]]'' confused the British politician with [[Edward Ponsonby, 8th Earl of Bessborough|Lord Bessborough]].<ref>''[[The Times]]'', December 2, 1920.</ref> Lord Desborough died in 1945. * '''Jhulri Devi''' was officially declared dead in 1974 and chased off her farm by relatives in order to steal her land in [[Uttar Pradesh]], India. After many years of legal delays, her 'death' was only annulled in 1999, by when she had reached the age of 85, after intervention by the [[Association of the Dead]], an organisation that protests such cases. (See also [[#B|Lal Bihari]].)<ref name="time.com"/><ref name="tribuneindia.com">[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/images/nation.htm#9 "'Dead' to come alive against Vajpayee"], ''[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]'', July 24, 1999.</ref> * '''[[Timothy Dexter|Lord Timothy Dexter]]:''' The self named 'lord,' eccentric Timothy Dexter was a wealthy American when he decided to fake his own death and throw a funeral. About three thousand people attended to mourn his passing, and a large celebration was held, with expensive wines and fine foods. However, it was discovered that he was not in fact dead when Dexter [[Caning|caned]] his wife for smiling and not looking sad.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://priceonomics.com/the-strange-life-of-lord-timothy-dexter/|title=The Strange Life of 'Lord' Timothy Dexter|newspaper=Priceonomics|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Joe DiMaggio]]''': The baseball player was reported dead in a broadcast by [[NBC]] in January 1999 as a text report running along the bottom of the television screen. The text, which DiMaggio himself saw, had been prepared following newspaper reports that DiMaggio was near death, and was transmitted when a technician pressed the wrong button.<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/news/1999/01/25/tv_dimaggio/ "We must be in heaven together"], ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', January 25, 1999.</ref> DiMaggio died in March 1999, 2 months after the report. [[File:Drusus minor (Museo del Prado) 01.jpg|thumb|[[Drusus Julius Caesar]]: A premature poem in his memory led to the poet's execution.]] *'''[[Ronnie James Dio]]:''' The singer was erroneously reported dead in the early morning hours of May 16, 2010, by MetalUnderground.com. A retraction was soon issued, but Dio was in fact suffering from stomach cancer and died later that morning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=55907|title=Ronnie James Dio Passes Away (Original)|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=55908|title=Ronnie James Dio IS <del>NOT</del> DEAD|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=55917|title=Ronnie James Dio Dies At Age 67|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Celine Dion]]''': On October 24, 2013, circulating messages designed to look like news headlines reported that the singer died.<ref name="Hoax slayer"/> *'''[[Fats Domino]]''': The musician was thought drowned during the [[Hurricane Katrina]] flooding that affected his [[Ninth Ward]], [[New Orleans]], neighborhood. After a few days, Domino reappeared, saying that he had evacuated to a friend's home in [[Baton Rouge]]. Domino died in October 2017, 12 years after the reports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1100547,00.html|title=Musician Fats Domino Spotted Among Survivors|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Kirk Douglas]]''': The actor had a draft obituary of his leaked on ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine's Web site on November 30, 2014, with the header "DO NOT PUB" still attached. Douglas, aged 97, was in good health at the time of the false report.<ref>Grisham, Lori (December 1, 2014). [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2014/11/30/people-magainze-posts-kirk-douglas-obit/19721703/ Kirk Douglas' obit published by mistake on 'People' website]. ''USA Today''. Retrieved December 1, 2014.</ref> *'''[[Hilary Duff]]''': The ''[[Lizzie McGuire]]'' actress and singer was reported dead in August 2011 by a hoax website claiming that she fell off Kauri Cliffs in New Zealand.<ref>[https://www.eonline.com/news/257462/hilary-duff-killed-off-by-internet-hoax ]. ''E! Online''. Retrieved September 19, 2018.</ref> *'''[[Drusus Julius Caesar]]:''' during a period of illness, the Roman politician was in 21 AD the subject of a eulogistic [[panegyric]] by the poet [[Clutorius Priscus]], which was prematurely rehearsed in front of some noblewomen at the home of [[Publius Petronius]]. The poet, who was seeking to replicate earlier success in a panegyric written after the passing of [[Germanicus]], was himself condemned to death by the Roman Senate for anticipating the death of the Emperor's son.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Internet Classics Archive {{!}} The Annals by Tacitus|url = http://classics.mit.edu/Tacitus/annals.3.iii.html|website = classics.mit.edu|accessdate = November 25, 2015}}</ref> *'''[[Ian Dury]]''': The English musician was pronounced dead on [[Xfm]] radio by [[Bob Geldof]] in 1998, possibly due to hoax information from a listener disgruntled at the station's change of ownership. The incident caused music magazine ''[[NME]]'' to call Geldof "the world's worst DJ".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/330571.stm "Radio stars await awards"], [[BBC]] News web site, April 28, 1999</ref> Dury died in March 2000. *'''[[Danny Dyer]]''': In January 2015, a hoax spread on Facebook claimed that the ''[[EastEnders]]'' actor had died at the age of 37. Dyer posted to Twitter to deny the rumor.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/dyer.asp | title=Dyer Faker | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref>
==E== [[File:Prince Philip March 2015 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]] was a subject of a premature obituary by [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|''The Sun'']].]] *'''[[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]]''' was falsely reported dead by [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|''The Sun'']] on May 4, 2017. The article was published on the internet after Queen [[Elizabeth II]] had called an emergency meeting to announce that the Duke was going to give up his royal engagements.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/prince-philip-dead-queen-elizabeth-ii-the-sun-mistake-buckingham-palace-emergency-meeting-royal-a7716861.html|title=The Sun mistakenly reports Prince Philip is dead|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=May 4, 2017|accessdate=May 5, 2017}}</ref> *'''[[Guy Edwards]]''' was reported dead overnight on October 16, 2018, according to motorsports website ''[[Autosport]]''. Subsequently, a former colleague of Edwards visited him in Ireland and confirmed he was still alive.<ref>{{cite web |title=Correction: Guy Edwards |url=https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/139417/correction-guy-edwards |website=[[Autosport]] |publisher=[[Motorsport Network]] |accessdate=16 October 2018 |date=16 October 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Harry Elionsky]]''' was reported dead on October 13, 1918, during the [[1918 flu pandemic]]. Several books list his death in 1918 as fact, including ''Hunting the 1918 flu: one scientist's search for a killer virus'' and ''The plague of the Spanish lady: the influenza pandemic of 1918–1919''. Both repeat the error from the 1918 papers. He went on to set records for distance swimming into the 1920s,<ref>{{Cite news|author= |title=Report Incorrect That Elionsky, Swimmer, Is Dead |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/714940532.html?dids=714940532:714940532&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&date=Oct+14,+1918&author=&pub=Boston+Daily+Globe&desc=REPORT+INCORRECT+THAT+ELIONSKY,+SWIMMER,+IS+DEAD&pqatl=google |quote= |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=October 14, 1918 |accessdate=July 22, 2010 }}</ref> and died in 1956. *'''[[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother]]'''{{'}}s death was erroneously announced in the Australian media in 1993 after a London-based [[Sky News]] employee saw an internal rehearsal for her future death (one of many conducted by the UK media over the years). Thinking it was for real, he phoned his mother in Australia with the 'news', who passed it on to the media.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/queenmother/article/0,,677156,00.html Ezard, J.: "A life of legend, duty and devotion"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', April 1, 2002.</ref> The time zone difference may have made it difficult for the Australian media to check the story during UK night-time. The employee was dismissed for the mistake, but then won a lawsuit for [[wrongful dismissal]]. (Fragments of the Queen Mother's life history also appeared in several other world figures' premature obituaries in the [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN.com incident]].) The Queen Mother died on March 30, 2002. *'''[[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]]'''{{'}}s death was announced on [[BBC WM]] on May 17, 2010. Host Danny Kelly played ''[[God Save the Queen]]'', then announced that "Queen Elizabeth II has now died." He was stopped by his producer, and later admitted that the announcement was meant as a joke: the Queen Elizabeth II who had died was a Facebook user who used the Queen's name. The chairman of Mediawatch-UK said in response, "Because it's the Queen and they treated it like a big announcement, it makes things worse ... It's the BBC we are talking about here, and there's a certain expectation from them."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/west_midlands/8688799.stm "BBC sorry for joking Queen had died."] BBC News, May 18, 2010 Retrieved on November 30, 2017.</ref> *'''Marjorie Halcrow Erskine''' (also known as '''Marjorie Elphinstone'''), a resident of [[Chirnside]] (possibly Ardtannies), Scotland, was presumed dead and buried in 1674 in a shallow grave by a sexton, who returned later to steal her jewellery. When he tried to cut off her finger to remove a ring, she revived and let out a groan. The robbers fled, and she walked home.<ref name="snopes"/> *'''[[Nora Ephron]]''': the American writer, who was in poor health, was falsely declared dead in a report from gossip columnist [[Liz Smith (journalist)|Liz Smith]] on June 26, 2012.<ref>Randall, Eric (June 26, 2012). [http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2012/06/wowowow-prematurely-publishes-nora-ephrons-obituary/53949/# Wowowow Prematurely Publishes Nora Ephron Obituary]. ''The Atlantic''. Retrieved June 26, 2012.</ref> Ephron died later that day. *'''[[David Ervine]]''': the Northern Irish politician suffered a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] and [[cerebral hemorrhage|brain haemorrhage]] on January 7, 2007. The [[RTÉ News: Nine O'Clock|RTÉ News at 9pm]] led with the news that he had died, correcting the error later in the bulletin. RTÉ's web site also reported him dead. Ervine died the following afternoon.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.unison.ie/irish_independent/stories.php3?ca=9&si=1751140&issue_id=15081 |title='It was all my mistake and I regret the hurt,' says Gorman |quote=RTÉ's Northern editor [[Tommie Gorman]], speaking live during Sunday's nine o'clock news, said that Mr Ervine had died after suffering a massive heart attack. He went on to give an overview of Mr Ervine's political life. Newsreader [[Anne Doyle]] corrected the error later in the bulletin. |first=Jason |last=O'Brien |date=January 9, 2007 |accessdate=April 5, 2007 |work =[[Irish Independent]] (free registration required)}}</ref>
==F== *'''[[Frederick Fane]]''', cricketer, reported in ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'' 1956 edition as having died on December 9, 1954. The 1961 edition reported his real death, aged 85, on November 27, 1960, saying: "Owing to a similarity of initials, Wisden reported his death when he was 79. The man concerned was Francis L. Fane, his cousin. By a coincidence, Mr Fane's father also once read his own obituary."<ref>''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'', 1956 edition, Obituaries, page 977.</ref><ref>''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'', 1961 edition, Obituaries, page 945.</ref> * '''Frederick John Fane''' (cricketer),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/116/116368/116368.html|title=The Home of CricketArchive|website=cricketarchive.com|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> father of Frederick Fane (see above). According to ''Wisden'' 1961, he too suffered a premature obituary, though no details were given. *'''[[Dorothy Fay]]''' (film actress, also called Dorothy Southworth Ritter), was declared dead in an August 2001 ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]'' obituary. Mrs Ritter, who lived in a nursing home, had been taken to another room temporarily when a friend stopped by to visit. On hearing that Mrs Ritter was "gone", the friend telephoned the ''Telegraph'' obituary editor.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/life/2006-06-21-obit_x.htm Wilson, C.: "Death is the story of their lives"], ''[[USA Today]]'', June 21, 2006.</ref> Fay died in November 2003. *'''[[Freddy Fender]]''' ([[Tejano music|Tex-Mex]] musician) was falsely reported dead in a 2001 report from ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. Fender laughed off the false report at the time.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fernandez |first=Sara Lee |title=Qué pasó: Despite magazine report, Fender's OK |url=http://web.caller.com/2001/march/16/today/localnew/20398.html |accessdate=May 2, 2014 |newspaper=CC Caller Times |date=March 16, 2001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502232321/http://web.caller.com/2001/march/16/today/localnew/20398.html |archivedate=May 2, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Fender died in 2006. *'''[[Will Ferrell]]''' (comedian), reported by iNewswire to have died in a paragliding accident on March 14, 2006. The press release was a hoax; Ferrell had never been paragliding.<ref>[http://www.regrettheerror.com/press-releases/will-ferrell-is-not-dead-not-paragliding "Will Ferrell is not dead, not paragliding"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201163058/http://www.regrettheerror.com/press-releases/will-ferrell-is-not-dead-not-paragliding |date=December 1, 2008 }}, RegretTheError.com, March 14, 2006. Includes text of iNewswire press release and Google News summary</ref> * '''Terry L. Fergerson''', a teacher from West Monroe, New York, US, was thought to have died in May 2006 when Terry L. Ferguson (differently spelled last name) was killed in a vehicle collision. When Fergerson arrived at work the following day, he found fellow teachers and students consoling each other over his death; various friends and relatives also thought he had died. It is not clear whether the confusion was made by them, local media or the police. In addition to their similar names, Fergerson and the real victim both drove red Chevy pickups and were of similar age. "I don't know what the percentages are, I'm not a mathematician, but it's pretty far out", Fergerson said.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071113190753/http://news.ewoss.com/articles/D8HDSLMG0.aspx "Teacher mistakenly reported dead"], [[Associated Press]] (cited on eWoss.com), May 5, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://domsweirdnews.blogspot.com/2006/05/reports-of-my-death-are-exaggerated.html "Reports of my death are exaggerated"] (longer but unattributed version of Associated Press story).</ref> * '''[[Lou Ferrigno]]''': On May 29, 2014. Santa Barbara, California police claimed that Lou Ferrigno died in a car accident.<ref name="Hoax slayer"/> * '''Sebastiao Fidelis''': a Brazilian man whose supposed body was identified by his wife and buried in 2001 after he had been missing for two months. A year later, he was found wandering in the area, having lost his memory.<ref>"Brazilian turns up alive and well a year after his 'burial'", [[Ananova]], January 8, 2003, cited on [http://www.leonardrossiter.com/reginaldperrin/Real.html Reggie Online].</ref> *'''[[Gerald Ford]]''' (former US President) in the [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN.com incident]]. Ford died in December 2006. *'''[[Matt Frewer]]''': according to the 2008 book ''Truth and Rumors: The Reality Behind TV's Most Famous Myths'', Frewer was once the subject of a premature obituary. However, no further details are given.<ref name="books.google.com"/>
==G== [[File:Marcus Garvey 1924-08-05.jpg|thumb|[[Marcus Garvey]] died after reading his own obituary.]]
*'''[[Zsa Zsa Gabor]]''': In early 2011, many websites, including her English Wikipedia page<ref>The first assertion of Gabor's death on English Wikipedia that year was on March 6, 2011, but there the actual rumor appears to have been on March 29 and 30.</ref> reported the death of Zsa Zsa Gabor. However, it was quickly revealed that she had not actually died, and that this was a hoax mistaken by several websites as fact. She died on December 18, 2016. * '''S. Gandaruban''': This Sri Lankan man living in Singapore faked his own death in 1987 and fled the country to escape creditors after his car rental business collapsed. He then arranged for a fake death certificate stating that he had been shot dead in crossfire. His brother and wife were convicted of their involvement. In 2007, he was charged with conspiring to claim extensive life insurance arising from the fake death.<ref>[http://www.lankatimes.com/fullstory.php?id=3431 "Lankan charged for faking own death"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204071344/http://www.lankatimes.com/fullstory.php?id=3431 |date=December 4, 2008 }}, LankaTimes.com, date unknown (retrieved December 4, 2007).</ref> *'''[[Marcus Garvey]]''': After suffering a stroke in {{start date|1940|01}}, the [[black nationalism|black nationalist]] read his obituary in the ''[[Chicago Defender]]'' which described him as "broke, alone and unpopular". Apparently as a result, Garvey suffered a second stroke and died.<ref name="20010119TAE" /> *'''[[Gordon Gee]]''': In March 2003 the then- [[Vanderbilt University]] president was declared dead by a fake edition of the university's student newspaper ''The Vanderbilt Hustler'', sparking early dismissal from classes, tears, and moments of silence. Gee issued a press release confirming he was still alive. The hoax was perpetrated by staff from a separate student satirical magazine ''The Slant'', whose managing editor would only say: "I have the right to remain silent, and I am exercising my right of silence".<ref>{{Cite news| last = Berger | first = Meredith | url=http://www.vanderbilthustler.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2003/03/14/3e71a2dbcee09 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031229152518/http://www.vanderbilthustler.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2003/03/14/3e71a2dbcee09 | archivedate=December 29, 2003 | title = Slant hoax ends in apologies |work = The Vanderbilt Hustler | date = March 14, 2003 | accessdate = October 11, 2007}}</ref> *'''[[Ghazali Shafie]]''', then [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Malaysia)|Foreign Minister]] of [[Malaysia]], was reported by ''[[The New York Times]]'' to have died in an aeroplane crash in 1982. Ghazali had in fact survived the crash, read his obituaries, and lived until 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/obituaries/mohammed-ghazali-bin-shafie-malaysian-official-dies-in-crash.html|title=Mohammad Ghazali bin Shafie, Malaysian official, dies in crash|date=January 11, 1982|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=January 25, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XAsfAAAAIBAJ&pg=5700,4726343&dq=ghazali-shafie+obituary|title=Envoy Survives|date=January 11, 1982|publisher=The Pittsburgh Press (United Press International)|accessdate=January 25, 2010}}</ref> *'''[[Gabrielle Giffords]]''': Giffords, a former member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] and a [[Gun control in the United States|gun safety]] advocate, has twice been the victim of a premature obituary. Giffords was one of numerous people shot during a meeting with constituents outside a grocery store in [[Tucson, Arizona]] on January 8, 2011.<ref name=police_actively>"[http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/01/08/arizona.shooting/index.html Police 'actively pursuing' second person in Tucson shooting]", CNN Wire Staff, CNN.com, January 8, 2011.</ref> Giffords sustained a serious gunshot wound to the head, but was not one of the six people immediately killed by the attack.<ref name=police_actively /> [[NPR]] erroneously reported that she had been killed, however, and that report was picked up and circulated by numerous other media outlets, including [[CNN]],<ref name=hagey>Hagey, Keach. "[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0111/47282.html NPR: 'We regret the erroneous news']", Politico, January 8, 2011.</ref> [[Fox News Channel]],<ref name=hagey /> ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name=hagey /> and [[Reuters]].<ref name=congresswoman_killed>"[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN0824535020110108 US congresswoman killed, others injured in shooting]", Reuters, January 8, 2011.</ref> In February 2017, U.S. Representative [[Sean Duffy]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Wisconsin|WI]]) erroneously claimed in a CNN [[New Day (TV Series)|New Day]] interview that Giffords died in the [[2011 Tucson shooting|2011 mass shooting]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Simpson|first1=Jeff|title=Sean Duffy Kills Gabby Giffords|url=http://cognidissidence.blogspot.com/2017/02/sean-duffy-kills-gabby-giffords.html|website=Cognitive Dissidence|accessdate=February 8, 2017}}</ref> *'''[[Cookie Gilchrist]]''': Gilchrist, a former fullback in the [[Canadian Football League]] and [[American Football League]], was presumed dead by his hospice worker on January 8, 2011, and reported the news to his nephew, Thomas Gilchrist. However, upon laying him down, Cookie was revived. Gilchrist died two days later.<ref name="espn-gilchrist">Graham, Tim (January 11, 2011). [http://espn.go.com/blog/afceast/post/_/id/24656/cookie-gilchrist-rumbled-right-until-the-end Cookie Gilchrist rumbled right until the end]. ''ESPN.com''. Retrieved January 11, 2011.</ref> *'''[[Terry Gilliam]]''': On September 8, 2015, the web site of the show business trade publication ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' briefly posted a premature obituary of director, animator, and ''[[Monty Python]]'' troupe member Terry Gilliam. ''Variety'' soon removed the post and apologized for the mistake; Gilliam followed by posting the message ""I APOLOGIZE FOR BEING DEAD especially to those who have already bought tickets to the upcoming talks, but, ''Variety'' has announced my demise. Don't believe their retraction and apology!" on his [[Facebook]] page.<ref name="gilliam">{{cite journal |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/09/terry-gilliam-dead-monty-python-variety-blunder |title=Terry Gilliam laughs off Variety's dead Python blunder |last=Child |first=Ben |date=September 9, 2015 |journal=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> *'''[[Jeff Goldblum]]''': On June 25, 2009, the same day actress [[Farrah Fawcett]] and musician [[Michael Jackson]] died, actor Jeff Goldblum was reported dead on Australia's [[Nine Network|Channel Nine]] news. The report was quickly debunked, and traced back to a hoax website.<ref>{{Cite news| last = Hurst | first = Daniel | url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/lifestyle/how-net-spoof-killed-jeff-goldblum-20090626-cywm.html | title = How net spoof 'killed' Jeff Goldblum |work = Brisbane Times | date = June 26, 2009 | accessdate = June 26, 2009}}</ref> * '''[[Roger Goodell]]''': The [[History of the NFL Commissioner|commissioner]] of the [[National Football League]] was subject to a death hoax on June 7, 2016, when hackers broke into the league's [[Twitter]] account and announced his death. Goodell was golfing with [[Jim Kelly]] at the time of the hoax.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/roger-goodell-twitter-hacked-death-hoax-reaction-060716|title=Roger Goodell jokes about Twitter death hoax {{!}} FOX Sports|date=June 7, 2016|newspaper=FOX Sports|language=en-US|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> * '''Harry Gordon''': in 2000, this Australian businessman faked his own death in a boating accident so his wife could claim a fortune in life insurance, though he claimed it was to evade business and relationship problems. He assumed a new identity and fled to Spain, then to England (where he worked in a potato crisp warehouse), South Africa, and New Zealand. He explained gaps in his past to a new girlfriend by telling her he was on a witness protection programme. He was discovered in 2005 and later jailed when, his brother encountered him on a mountain path in New Zealand. Gordon published a book about his exploits, titled ''How I Faked My Own Death''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sundaystartimes/4144431a24815.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120918053946/http://www.stuff.co.nz/sundaystartimes/4144431a24815.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 18, 2012 |title=The man who faked his own death: Harry Gordon |date=July 29, 2007 |work=[[The Sunday Star-Times]] |accessdate=October 15, 2011 }}</ref> *'''[[Frank Gorshin]]''' ([[Riddler|The Riddler]] from ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]''): in 1957, after driving 39 hours without a break to avoid flying to a screen test, the actor fell asleep at the wheel and crashed. A Los Angeles newspaper reported him dead. Gorshin was unconscious for four days, and the role went to another actor.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/05/19/db1903.xml "Frank Gorshin"], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', May 19, 2005.</ref> Gorshin died in May 2005. *'''[[Gotye]]''': In July 2012, CNN reported that the Australian [[indie rock]] singer committed suicide. The report was disproven by the singer himself, who replied on Twitter that he was in fact alive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/gotye/64651|title=NME News Gotye takes to Twitter to deny reports of his death – NME.COM|date=July 2, 2012|work=NME.COM}}</ref> * '''Nicephorus Glycas''': in 1896, having presumably been declared dead, the Greek Orthodox bishop of [[Lesbos Island]] awoke in his coffin after he had been lying in state for two days. He sat up and asked what mourners were staring at.<ref name="Pile, S. 1979">Pile, S.: ''The Book of Heroic Failures'', Routledge Kegan & Paul, 1979.</ref> *'''[[Robert Graves]]''': the writer was left for dead in 1916 after receiving life-threatening injuries at the [[Battle of the Somme]]. He made a remarkable recovery, and read a report of his death in ''[[The Times]]''.<ref>[http://www.robertgraves.org/bio.php#one Firla, I.: "Robert Graves: a critical biography"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019064431/http://www.robertgraves.org/bio.php |date=October 19, 2006 }}, St John's College Robert Graves Trust web site.</ref> Graves died in 1985. * '''Ann Green''' (or '''Anne Greene'''), a servant in [[Oxfordshire]], was hanged for allegedly murdering her newborn child in 1650. Having presumably been declared dead, her corpse was taken away for dissection, but she revived. She was ultimately pardoned, and became something of a celebrity.<ref>[http://www.jrsm.org/cgi/content/full/95/3/157 Carter, R.: "Bodies politic"], ''Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine'' 95:157–159, 2002.</ref><ref>[http://www.marshallsgroup.com/Duns%20Tew.htm "Duns Tew"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928134826/http://www.marshallsgroup.com/Duns%20Tew.htm |date=September 28, 2007 }}, Marshalls Chartered Surveyors web site.</ref> * '''Catherine Sophie Greenhill''', a British three-year-old who was pronounced dead after falling from an upper storey window onto flagstones in the late 18th century. However, she was revived by a Dr. (or Mr.) Squires, a member of the recently formed Society for the Recovery of Persons Apparently Drowned (later the [[Royal Humane Society]]) using an early form of defibrillator. After a time in coma she eventually made a full recovery.<ref>R.S. Atkinson and T.V. Boulton (eds.): ''The History Of Anesthesia'', cited in [http://www.alcor.org/Library/html/PersonsApparentlyDead.htm Harris, S.B.: "The Society for the Recovery of Persons Apparently Dead"], ''Cryonics'', September 1990.</ref> *'''[[Sasha Grey]]''': In February 2015, it was reported that the actress had been captured and killed by Ukrainian military forces. Grey herself took to Twitter to dispel such rumors.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/sashagrey.asp | title=Sasha Grey Dead? | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 25, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Friedrich Gulda]]''' (pianist), who in 1999 faxed the Austrian News Agency claiming he had died of a stroke at [[Zürich Airport|Zurich Airport]]. Shortly afterwards he announced he was still alive and would be giving a 'Resurrection Recital', which was accompanied by go-go dancers (he often played pranks to annoy the musical establishment).<ref>[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20000202 /ai_n14286524 Anderson, M.: "Obituary: Friedrich Gulda"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110200814/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20000202 |date=January 10, 2016 }}, ''[[The Independent]]'', February 2, 2000 (the obituary upon Gulda's actual death)</ref> Gulda died in 2000. * '''Dominic Guzzetta''': in November 2005, the former [[University of Akron]] president was reported by the ''[[Akron Beacon Journal]]'' to have been 'posthumously honored' at a fundraising event. Prior to this, he had joked for years that he reads the obituaries to make sure his name is not among them.<ref>[http://www.regrettheerror.com/newspapers/paper-posthumously-honors-living-man "Paper posthumously honors living man"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627043511/http://www.regrettheerror.com/newspapers/paper-posthumously-honors-living-man |date=June 27, 2009 }}, RegretTheError.com, November 23, 2005.</ref> *'''[[Chespirito|Roberto Gómez Bolaños]]''': The well-known actor, known by the name "Chespirito", was reported dead in 2003 by a confused Chilean reporter (Carolina Zúñiga). Actually the dead person was a Chilean writer with a similar name ([[Roberto Bolaño]]). Chespirito died in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=262160|title=Los peores chascarros que ha entregado el creativo mundo periodstico nacional|work=Emol}}</ref>
==H== *'''[[Gene Hackman]]''': On January 27, 2015, a rumor spread on social media that actor Gene Hackman had died at the age of 85. The source stems from a news article that referenced not his death, but his retirement; and many readers who saw the article's headline assumed that he had died.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/genehackmandead.asp |title=Gene Hoaxman |publisher=[[Snopes]] |accessdate=October 25, 2016}}</ref> *[[Lincoln Hall (climber)|'''Lincoln Hall''']]: In 2006, Lincoln Hall was climbing up [[Mount Everest|Mt. Everest]] with a group of climbers, one of whom, Thomas Weber, had already died. Although Hall had made it to the summit, he was suffering from what was probably [[cerebral edema]], and on the way down was abandoned for dead by his [[Sherpas]], after beginning to hallucinate and refuse to move. When the rest of the expedition reached ground, the leader, Alexander Abramov reported Hall had died on the way down, and Hall's family was informed. However, the day after the event, Dan Mazur found Hall sitting on a ledge, 28,200 feet up, with no oxygen. Hall had survived the night in the fabled '[[death zone]],' near the top of Mt Everest. Hall would die of mesothelioma in 2012 at his home in Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5019288.stm|title='Dead' Everest man safe at camp|publisher=BBC News|access-date=December 11, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/25/world/asia/lincoln-hall-australian-mountaineer-dies-at-56.html|title=Lincoln Hall, Australian Mountaineer, Dies at 56|last=Weber|first=Bruce|date=March 24, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=December 11, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Holly Hallstrom]]''': Various rumors spread on the Internet and [[social media]] that former [[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|Price is Right]] model Holly Hallstrom died March 25, 2017, often paired with a similar rumor that fellow model [[Janice Pennington]] also died early that same year. Neither report is true, and both are currently alive and well. *'''[[Corinna Harfouch]]''': the German actress was reported dead by a Swiss newspaper when she fell into a river during filming and was swept away. In fact, she survived and phoned her ex-husband, who had seen the obituary, from hospital to confirm that she was alive.<ref>[http://www.shortnews.de/start.cfm?id=477488 "Corinna Harfouch fast ertrunken" (German)]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}, Shortnews, September 19, 2003.</ref> *'''[[Angelo Hays]]''': the French Inventor and celebrity was in a motorcycle accident in 1937. The doctors were unable to find a pulse and Hays was declared dead. He was buried three days later in the village of St. Quentin de Chalais. Two days after the funeral, when Hays was exhumed for the purposes of an insurance investigation, forensic examiners were surprised to find that the body was still warm. They found that Hays had been in a coma resulting from his head injury; his body's diminished need for oxygen had allowed him to survive for two days underground.<ref name=marshall>{{cite web|last=Marshall|first=Kelli|title=4 People Who Were Buried Alive (And How They Got Out)|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/54818/4-people-who-were-buried-alive-and-how-they-got-out|work=mentalfloss|accessdate=February 18, 2014|date=February 15, 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Jon Heder]]''': an American actor, who was made famous by his role as [[Napoleon Dynamite]], was rumored to have died in a car crash in 2005. Another rumor was that he died from an overdose. In an interview in March 2005 by Misty Harris of [[Canwest News Service]], when asked about the rumors of his death, Heder said, "Yeah, and apparently it's not true."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.snopes.com/movies/actors/heder.asp|title=Jon Heder Death Rumor|last=Mikkelson|first=David|newspaper=snopes|language=en-US|access-date=December 11, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Hugh Hefner]]''': On July 11, 2011, the [[Playboy]] entrepreneur was reported dead of a heart attack.<ref name="About entertaining">{{cite web|url=http://urbanlegends.about.com/od/celebrities/ss/Celebrity-Responses-To-Fake-Death-Notices.htm|title=Funniest Celebrity Responses to Fake Death Reports|author=David Emery|work=About.com Entertainment}}</ref> Hefner died on September 27, 2017. [[File:Ernest_and_Mary_Hemingway_on_safari,_1953-54.jpg|thumb|[[Ernest Hemingway]] and [[Mary Welsh Hemingway]] in Africa in 1954. Both were hurt in plane crashes during their trip and were reported dead]] *'''[[Ernest Hemingway]]''' and '''[[Mary Welsh Hemingway]]''': After the husband and wife authors were involved in two African plane crashes in 1954, newspapers reported that both had died. They survived, but Ernest Hemingway suffered extensive injuries which affected him for the rest of his life. AE Hotchner claimed that after the incident, Hemingway read a scrapbook of his obituaries every morning with a glass of champagne.<ref>[http://encarta.msn.com/media_461577223/Ernest_Hemingway_Quick_Facts.html "Ernest Hemingway quick facts"], MSN Encarta (retrieved on February 13, 2007). [https://www.webcitation.org/query?id=1257023934907388 Archived] October 31, 2009.</ref> Ernest Hemingway committed suicide in 1961.<ref>"[[Ernest Hemingway]]"</ref> Mary Welsh Hemingway died in 1986. *'''[[Bill Henry]]''' (American baseball player): newspapers and the [[Associated Press]] reported him dead in August 2007 after the death of a similar-looking retired salesman of the same name. The dead man had claimed for decades that he was the retired sportsman — even to his wife and stepchildren — and had explained away discrepancies in his story, such as Bill Henry's name and place of birth on baseball cards, as printing errors. The fraud came to light when a genealogist investigated the incorrect date of birth published in the obituaries.<ref name="Henry">[http://www.theledger.com/article/20070905/NEWS/709050475/1004 "Lakeland Man Wasn't Who He Said He Was"], TheLedger.com, September 5, 2007</ref> The real Bill Henry died in 2014. *'''[[Michael Heseltine]]''': In 1994, then-DJ [[Chris Morris (satirist)|Chris Morris]] implied on [[BBC Radio 1]] (as a prank) that the British politician had died. This led to an on-air tribute by fellow [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Jerry Hayes]] (during which Morris managed to make Hayes laugh inappropriately), and Morris' subsequent suspension. (See also [[#S|Jimmy Savile]].)<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1460463.stm Walker, A.: "Chris Morris: Brass Neck"], [[BBC]] News web site, July 27, 2001.</ref> * '''Carl Hilderbrandt''': a British businessman who jumped bail in 1990 on theft charges and [[Pseudocide|faked his suicide]] by drowning, presumably resulting in his being declared dead. He started a new life in America, but years later was identified by a British tourist and eventually prosecuted.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F2000%2F04%2F21%2Fnfake21.html Stokes, P.: "'Reggie Perrin' fugitive is caught in Florida"], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', April 21, 2000.</ref> *'''[[Christopher Hitchens]]''': From the British atheism advocate's real-life obituary, after he had died in December 2011: "Hitchens had quotable ideas about posterity, clarified years ago when he saw himself referred to as 'the late' Christopher Hitchens in print."<ref>Italie, Hillel (December 16, 2011). [http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_OBIT_HITCHENS?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2011-12-16-05-28-21 Christopher Hitchens, militant pundit, dies at 62]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Associated Press. Retrieved December 16, 2011.</ref> * '''Cockie Hoogterp''', the second wife of [[Bror von Blixen-Finecke|Baron Blixen]], was declared dead in a 1936 [[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]] obituary after the Baron's third wife died in an auto accident. Mrs. Hoogterp sent all her bills back marked "Deceased" and ordered the Telegraph to print that "Mrs. Hoogterp wishes it to be known that she has not yet been screwed in her coffin."<ref>[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_v39/ai_5091234 Buckley, P.L.: "Out in the noonday sun",] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310225209/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_v39/ai_5091234 |date=March 10, 2007 }} ''[[National Review]]'', July 31, 1987</ref> *'''[[Lena Horne]]''': in 2008, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' online posted a premature obituary for the singer-actress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laist.com/2008/12/17/ew_onlines_lena_horne_obit_oops.php|title=EW Online's Lena Horne Obit 'Oops!'|work=LAist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218111918/http://laist.com/2008/12/17/ew_onlines_lena_horne_obit_oops.php|archivedate=December 18, 2008|df=}}</ref> Horne died on May 9, 2010. *'''[[Bob Hope]]''', twice. In both cases a pre-written obituary of the entertainer was accidentally published on a news web site: # In 1998 his obituary appeared on the [[Associated Press]] web site, leading to the announcement of his death in the [[United States House of Representatives]], broadcast live on [[C-SPAN]].<ref>[http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/HouseSession1679 House Proceeding – June 5, 1998] (6:01:45 from start). From [[C-SPAN]].</ref><ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-hope,1,6999733.story?coll=la-news-obituaries&ctrack=1&cset=true Martinez, A.: "The Master of the One-Liner"], ''Los Angeles Times'', July 29, 2003.</ref> # In the 2003 [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN.com incident]]. Hope's draft obituary, which had used the Queen Mother's as a template, described him as 'Queen Consort' and the 'UK's favorite grandmother'. Hope died just three months later. * '''Professor John Nicholas Peregrine Horden''', a Fellow of All Souls' College Oxford. An erroneous obituary was published by the Oxford University Gazette on October 2, 2008, and withdrawn in a subsequent issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/2008-9/weekly/301008/coll.htm|title=Oxford University Gazette, 30 October 2008: Colleges, Halls, and Societies|publisher=}}</ref> The confusion was caused by the recent death of his father, Professor John Horden. *'''[[Whitney Houston]]''', American singer, was falsely reported dead of a drug overdose on a radio report on September 12, 2001.<ref>Knolle, Sharon (September 13, 2001). [http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=102477&page=1 Reports of Whitney Houston's Death Denied]. ABC News. Retrieved February 12, 2012.</ref> Houston died on February 11, 2012. *'''[[Humphrey (cat)|Humphrey]]''', the [[Downing Street]] cat (or '[[Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office]]') under [[Margaret Thatcher]], [[John Major]], and [[Tony Blair]], was feared dead on two occasions: # In September 1995 a government press spokesman announced that Humphrey was presumed dead, as he had been missing since June. After the ensuing publicity, he was found to be alive and residing in the nearby Royal Army Medical College where he had been taken in as a stray. A statement was issued quoting Humphrey as saying: "I have had a wonderful holiday at the Royal Army Medical College, but it is nice to be back and I am looking forward to the new parliamentary session."<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/03/14/ndoss14.xml Millward, D.: "Humphrey... the Downing St dossier"], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', March 15, 2005.</ref> # In November 1997, there were media allegations that [[Cherie Blair]] disliked the cat so much that she had had him killed; the government claimed he had merely gone into retirement away from the public spotlight. In Parliament, [[Alan Clark]] MP demanded that the government prove Humphrey was still alive. As a result, the government released photographs of Humphrey posing with the day's newspapers as proof.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/politics/34455.stm "Purr-fect ending fur Humphrey!"], [[BBC News]], November 25, 1997.</ref> Humphrey's actual death was announced by Tony Blair March 2006.<ref>[[Humphrey (cat)|"Humphrey"]]</ref> *'''[[William Hung]]''': in 2004, a satirical news report on the ''[[Broken Newz]]'' web site claiming that the ''[[American Idol]]'' contestant had died of a heroin overdose was widely believed, forcing Hung to issue a denial.<ref>[http://www.snopes.com/music/artists/hung.asp "William Hung"], Snopes.com</ref> *'''[[Saddam Hussein]]''', former [[President of Iraq]], was reported dead in April 1980 by Radio [[Tehran]]. This incident took place during a diplomatic standoff between Iraq and Iran, culminating in the [[Iran–Iraq War]].<ref>Pierre Razoux. ''The Iran–Iraq War''. Cambridge University Press. 2015. P. 4.</ref> Saddam was executed on 30 December 2006. {{anchor|I}}
==I== *'''[[Gabriel Iglesias]]''': on November 1, 2014, a fake news article spread on Facebook claimed that the comedian had died. The next day, Iglesias posted a message assuring his fans that he was still alive.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/fluffydeathhoax.asp | title=The Death of Fluffy | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Samuel Israel III]]''': This former manager of the hedge fund [[Bayou Hedge Fund Group]] faked suicide. On June 9, 2008, his abandoned sports vehicle was found abandoned, with the words "[[Suicide Is Painless|suicide is painless]]" on the hood. He eventually turned himself in at the urging of his mom to serve the 20 years of prison he was sentenced to.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/03/business/03bayou.html|title=Fund Manager Who Faked His Suicide Surrenders|last=Bhattarai|first=Abha|date=July 3, 2008|last2=Schwartz|first2=Nelson D.|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=December 15, 2016}}</ref>
==J== [[File:Steve_Jobs_Headshot_2010-CROP.jpg|thumb|[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] published an obituary for [[Steve Jobs]] over three years before his death]] *'''[[Chris Jericho]]''': Wikipedia noted of Jericho's supposed death in April 2014. This was proven to be vandalism, and Jericho would jokingly tweet that he had died. Two months later, Wikipedia again listed Jericho as passing away in June 2014. Jericho would tweet that he has unfortunately 'died again', referencing the first hoax. *'''[[Jiang Zemin]]''': Amid internet rumors concerning his health, Hong Kong's [[Asia Television]] reported him dead on its 6 pm evening news broadcast on July 6, 2011. The next day, China's [[Xinhua News Agency]] dismissed reports of Jiang's death as "pure rumor", prompting ATV to retract its earlier report.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120619031327/http://hken.ibtimes.com/articles/176246/20110707/jiang-zemin-death-rumor-china-denies-and-atv-apologizes.htm|title=Wayback Machine|date=June 19, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Steve Jobs]]''': On August 27, 2008, [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] accidentally published a 17-page obituary. During a subsequent keynote address, Jobs joked about the accident by displaying on screen an imprecise quotation of Mark Twain (who was also the recipient of a premature obituary) reading "The reports of my death are greatly exaggerated".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/5042795/bloomberg-runs-steve-jobs-obituary |title=Steve Jobs's Obituary, As Run By Bloomberg |author=Ryan Tate |publisher=Gawker Media |work=Gawker |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65C7ZZaXf?url=http://gawker.com/5042795/bloomberg-runs-steve-jobs-obituary |archivedate=February 4, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article4628491.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Rumours of Steve Jobs demise greatly exaggerated by Bloomberg obituary | date=August 28, 2008 | accessdate=May 8, 2010 | first1=Suzy | last1=Jagger | first2=New | last2=York}}</ref> Jobs actually died of [[pancreatic cancer]] on October 5, 2011, at the age of 56. *'''[[Pope John Paul II]]''': *# Immediately after the [[Pope John Paul II assassination attempt|1981 attempt on his life]], despite heightened caution from [[CBS]]'s embarrassing premature obituary of [[James Brady]] weeks earlier, [[CNN]] implied the Pope had died by repeatedly referring to him in the past tense.<ref name="Castro, J.: The Pope's been shot!"/> *# In 2003, by CNN again, this time in the [[#The CNN.com incident|CNN.com incident]]. The draft obituary, which had used the Queen Mother's as a template, noted the Pope's 'love of racing'. *# On April 1, 2005, the day before his actual death, [[Fox News]] reported he had died after it received incorrect reports from the Italian media that his [[ECG]] had gone flat.<ref>[http://www.adweek.com/tvnewser/pope-on-fnc-shep-smith-declares-pope-dead-then-retracts-it/5833 "Pope: on FNC, Shep Smith declares Pope dead – then retracts it"], TVNewser, April 1, 2005. Retrieved March 27, 2016. Includes transcript and link to video.</ref> *'''[[Dwayne Johnson]]''': The American actor was falsely reported dead on April 12, 2014, but Johnson posted a photo on [[Instagram]] of him working out at the gym, which disproved the story. The report was the same as [[Robyn Malcolm]]'s death hoax – falling 60 feet down Kauri Cliffs in New Zealand. The initial report stated that Johnson was filming ''[[Fast and Furious 7]]'' at the time, which has no scheduled filming in New Zealand. If the news was true, it would have been the second death during production, after [[Paul Walker]]'s death in November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/dwayne-johnson-death-hoax-rock-died-filming-dangerous-stunt-fast-furious-7-1444491|title=Dwayne Johnson Death Hoax: The Rock 'Died Filming Dangerous Stunt for Fast & Furious 7'|work=International Business Times UK}}</ref> *'''Jay Jon''': in September 2014, a 17-year-old [[Brooklyn]]-based rapper was the subject of a death hoax. A Facebook post claimed that he was found dead on a sidewalk shortly after releasing a music video, C.O.P., on [[YouTube]]. The rumor still persisted for two months, until Jay Jon addressed the hoax.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/jayjon.asp | title=Jay Jon Dead? | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[George Jones]]''': the country singer was hospitalized on April 18, 2013, concurrently with a hoax report of his death beginning to circulate on the Internet. Jones's publicist denied the report and even went so far to say he was not even sick; however, Jones (who, at age 81, was engaged in his farewell tour<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pacella |first1=Megan |title=George Jones Announces Final Nashville Concert, More 2013 Tour Dates |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/george-jones-2013-tour-dates/ |website=Taste of Country |accessdate=April 1, 2017 |date=November 12, 2012}}</ref>) died eight days later. *'''[[James Earl Jones]]''': in 1998 the actor was mistakenly pronounced dead during a radio broadcast of a [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] baseball game by [[play-by-play]] announcer [[Lanny Frattare]]. Frattare had confused him with [[James Earl Ray]], [[Martin Luther King]]'s assassin, who had recently died.<ref>Johnson, L.A. "[http://www.post-gazette.com/magazine/19980824dead1.asp Web site keeps track of a very vital statistic of celebrities – their mortality]", the [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]], published August 24, 1998, accessed March 9, 2007.</ref><ref>Biertempfel, Rob. "[http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/sports/s_591193.html No doubt about it: Lanny Frattare retires] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202130812/http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/sports/s_591193.html |date=2 February 2009 }}", The Pittsburgh Tribune-Review, October 2, 2008.</ref><ref>"[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-19857826.html Pittsburgh announcer misses report on Ray's death]", The Associated Press, April 24, 1998.</ref> Jones was also the subject of an internet death hoax in August 2015, when a parody website posted news of his "death" which quickly spread via social media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/30/entertainment/james-earl-jones-not-dead-feat/|title=No, James Earl Jones is not dead – CNN|first=Lisa Respers France,|last=CNN|publisher=|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> *'''[[Michael Jordan]]''': in February 2015, a death hoax surfaced with the claim that the former NBA superstar had died of a heart attack in his sleep at the age of 52.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/michaeljordan.asp | title=Michael Jordan Death Hoax | publisher=[[Snopes]] | accessdate=October 25, 2016}}</ref> * '''Raid Juhi''': in March 2005 the presiding judge in the trial of [[Saddam Hussein]] was incorrectly reported by [[NBC News]] to have been assassinated. The real victims were another trial judge, Barbweez Mahmood, and his son. NBC blamed incorrect information from US officials.<ref>[http://www.regrettheerror.com/2005/03/nbc_names_wrong.html "NBC names wrong Iraqi judge"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021064830/http://www.regrettheerror.com/2005/03/nbc_names_wrong.html |date=October 21, 2006 }}, RegretTheError.com, March 4, 2005.</ref>
==K== * '''Kailash''' (full name unknown): this farm labourer from [[Uttar Pradesh]], India, was officially registered as dead by cousins in order to steal land he had inherited. He went to court, but the case was mired in legal delays, and his cousins beat him and threatened to kill him. "It is better to be dead on paper than to be really dead," he said. (See also [[List of premature obituaries#B|Lal Bihari]].)<ref name="time.com"/> * '''George Kaye''': in November 2005, the Irish musician was reported dead by the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' following a plane crash.<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-138254169.html, M.: "Kaye the King of Bluegrass got a look at his own obituary"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', November 5, 2005.</ref> *'''[[Ken Kesey]]''': in 1966, the author of ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (novel)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest]]'' faked his own suicide in an attempt to escape drug charges. He had friends leave his truck and a suicide note on a cliffside road in California, while he fled to Mexico. He later returned to the US, but was arrested and jailed for five months.<ref>[http://www.litweb.net/biography/334/Ken_Kesey.html Ken Kesey biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312045556/http://www.litweb.net/biography/334/Ken_Kesey.html |date=March 12, 2008 }} on LitWeb.net</ref> Kesey died in 2001. *'''[[Khushwant Singh]]''': an English writer from India wrote his own obituary in his mid twenties while he worked in [[Undivided India]] at [[Lahore]]. The title he chose for his obituary: ''[[wikt:posthumous|Posthumous]]''.<ref>[http://www.tehelka.com/story_main9.asp?filename=hub122504if_i_had.asp, M.: "The raunchy raconteur is now reflecting on death"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322232053/http://www.tehelka.com/story_main9.asp?filename=hub122504if_i_had.asp, |date=March 22, 2012 }}, ''[[Tehelka]]'', December 25, 2004.</ref> Singh actually died of natural causes at the age of 99 on March 20, 2014. *'''[[Rudyard Kipling]]''': His death had been incorrectly announced in a magazine, to which he wrote, "I've just read that I am dead. Don't forget to delete me from your list of subscribers." Kipling died in 1936. *'''[[Michael Kirchner|Michael "Corporal" Kirchner]]''', former professional wrestler, was reported dead in an article at WWE.com on October 15, 2006. He and his family were understandably confused and upset, and even after Kirchner confirmed that he was alive, the error was never officially retracted on WWE's website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2006/10/21/2087452.html|title=CANOE — SLAM! Sports – Wrestling – Cpl. Kirchner speaks: "I'm not dead!"|work=canoe.ca}}</ref> *'''[[K. Karunakaran]]''' (Indian politician, former [[Chief Minister of Kerala]], India): reportedly dead on November 12, 2009, when he was hospitalized with age-related complications. Karunakaran lived for another year and died in December 2010. *'''[[Wayne Knight]]''', an American actor, was reported dead in a motor vehicle accident on March 16, 2014.
