{{more footnotes|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox diagnostic | Name = Semen analysis | Image = Sperm stained.JPG | Alt = | Caption = Human sperm stained for [[semen quality]] testing in the clinical laboratory. | DiseasesDB =infertility | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = | MedlinePlus = 003627 | eMedicine = | MeshID = | LOINC = | HCPCSlevel2 = {{HCPCSlevel2|G|0027}} | Reference_range = }} A '''semen analysis''' (plural: semen analyses), also called "''seminogram''"{{cite journal | author = Lozano GM, Bejarano I, Espino J, González D, Ortiz A, García JF, Rodríguez AB, Pariente JA | year = 2009 | title = Density gradient capacitation is the most suitable method to improve fertilization and to reduce DNA fragmentation positive spermatozoa of infertile men | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/259983025_Density_gradient_capacitation_is_the_most_suitable_method_to_improve_fertilization_and_to_reduce_DNA_fragmentation_positive_spermatozoa_of_infertile_men | journal = Anatolian Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology | volume = 3 | issue = 1| pages = 1–7 }} evaluates certain characteristics of a male's [[semen]] and the [[spermatozoon|sperm]] contained therein. It is done to help evaluate male [[fertility]], whether for those seeking [[pregnancy]] or verifying the success of [[vasectomy]]. Depending on the measurement method, just a few characteristics may be evaluated (such as with a home kit) or many characteristics may be evaluated (generally by a diagnostic laboratory). Collection techniques and precise measurement method may influence results. ==Reasons for testing== The most common reasons for laboratory semen analysis in humans are as part of a couple's [[infertility]] investigation and after a [[vasectomy]] to verify that the procedure was successful. It is also commonly used for testing human donors for [[sperm donation]], and for animals semen analysis is commonly used in [[stud farming]] and farm [[animal breeding]]. Occasionally a man will have a semen analysis done as part of routine pre-pregnancy testing. At the laboratory level this is rare, as most healthcare providers will not test the semen and sperm unless specifically requested or there is a strong suspicion of a pathology in one of these areas discovered during the medical history or during the physical examination. Such testing is very expensive and time-consuming, and in the U.S. is unlikely to be covered by insurance. In other countries, such as Germany, the testing is covered by all insurances. ==Relation to fertility== The characteristics measured by semen analysis are only some of the factors in [[semen quality]]. One source states that 30% of men with a normal semen analysis actually have abnormal sperm function.{{cite web|title=Understanding Semen Analysis |publisher=Stonybrook, State University of New York |year=1999 |url=http://www.uhmc.sunysb.edu/urology/male_infertility/SEMEN_ANALYSIS.html |accessdate=2007-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017033415/http://www.uhmc.sunysb.edu/urology/male_infertility/SEMEN_ANALYSIS.html |archivedate=October 17, 2007 }} Conversely, men with poor semen analysis results may go on to father children.{{Cite book| edition = 5| publisher = Mosby| isbn = 978-0-323-08949-4| last1 = RN| first1 = Kathleen Deska Pagana PhD| last2 = FACS| first2 = Timothy J. Pagana MD| title = Mosby's Manual of Diagnostic and Laboratory Tests, 5e| location = St. Louis, Missouri| date = 2013-11-22}} In [[NICE guidelines]], ''mild male factor infertility'' is defined as when 2 or more semen analyses have 1 or more variables below the 5th [[percentile]], and confers a chance of pregnancy occurring naturally through vaginal intercourse within 2 years similar to people with mild [[endometriosis]].[http://guidance.nice.org.uk/CG156 Fertility: assessment and treatment for people with fertility problems]. [[NICE guidelines|NICE clinical guideline]] CG156 - Issued: February 2013 ==Collection methods== {{Main|Semen collection}} Different methods used for semen collection are [[masturbation]], condom collection and [[Epididymis|epididymal]] extraction, etc. The sample should never be obtained through coitus interruptus for several reasons: Some part of ejaculation could be lost, bacterial contamination could happen and the acid vaginal pH could be detrimental for sperm motility. The optimal sexual abstinence for semen sample obtaining is from 2–7 days. The most common way to obtain a semen sample is through masturbation and the best place to obtain it is in the clinic where the analysis will take place in order to avoid temperature changes during the transport that can be lethal for some spermatozoa. Once the sample is obtained, it must be put directly in a sterile plastic recipient (never in a conventional preservative since they have chemical substances as lubricants or spermicides that could damage the sample) and be handed in the clinic for it to be studied within the following hour. ==Parameters== Examples of parameters measured in a semen analysis are: sperm count, motility, morphology, volume, fructose level and pH. ===Sperm count=== [[Image:Success rates by amount of sperm.svg|thumb|right|250px|Approximate [[pregnancy rate]] varies with amount of sperm used in an artificial insemination cycle. Values are for intrauterine insemination, with sperm number in ''total sperm count'', which may be approximately twice the ''total motile sperm count''.]] Sperm count, or ''sperm concentration'' to avoid confusion with ''total sperm count'', measures the concentration of sperm in a man's ejaculate, distinguished from ''total sperm count'', which is the sperm count multiplied with volume. Over 15 million sperm per milliliter is considered normal, according to the WHO in 2010.{{cite journal |vauthors=Cooper TG, Noonan E, von Eckardstein S, Auger J, Baker HW, Behre HM, Haugen TB, Kruger T, Wang C, Mbizvo MT, Vogelsong KM | title = World Health Organization reference values for human semen characteristics. | journal = Human Reproduction Update | volume = 16 | issue = 3 | pages = 231–45 | date = May–Jun 2010 | pmid = 19934213 | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dmp048 | url = http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/topics/infertility/cooper_et_al_hru.pdf }} Older definitions state 20 million. A lower sperm count is considered [[oligospermia|oligozoospermia]]. A vasectomy is considered successful if the sample is [[Azoospermia|azoospermic]] (zero sperm of any kind found). Some define success as when rare/occasional non-motile sperm are observed (fewer than 100,000 per millilitre).{{cite journal |vauthors=Rajmil O, Fernández M, Rojas-Cruz C, Sevilla C, Musquera M, Ruiz-Castañe E | title = Azoospermia should not be given as the result of vasectomy | language = Spanish | journal = Arch. Esp. Urol. | volume = 60 | issue = 1 | pages = 55–8 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17408173 }}
{{cite journal |vauthors=Dhar NB, Bhatt A, Jones JS | title = Determining the success of vasectomy | journal = BJU Int. | volume = 97 | issue = 4 | pages = 773–6 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16536771 | doi = 10.1111/j.1464-410X.2006.06107.x }} Others advocate obtaining a second semen analysis to verify the counts are not increasing (as can happen with re-canalization) and others still may perform a repeat vasectomy for this situation. Chips for home use are emerging that can give an accurate estimation of sperm count after three samples taken on different days. Such a chip may measure the concentration of sperm in a semen sample against a control liquid filled with polystyrene beads.[http://www.popsci.com/technology/article/2010-01/counting-chip-provides-cheap-home-sperm-counting New Chip Provides Cheap At-Home Sperm Counting] By Stuart Fox Posted 01.26.2010 in Popular Science{{ums|date=December 2017}} ===Motility=== The [[World Health Organization]] has a value of 50% and this must be measured within 60 minutes of collection. WHO also has a parameter of ''vitality'', with a lower [[reference limit]] of 60% live spermatozoa. A man can have a total number of sperm far over the limit of 20 million sperm cells per milliliter, but still have bad quality because too few of them are motile. However, if the sperm count is very high, then a low motility (for example, less than 60%) might not matter, because the fraction might still be more than 8 million per millilitre. The other way around, a man can have a sperm count far less than 20 million sperm cells per millilitre and still have good motility, if more than 60% of those observed sperm cells show good forward movement - which is beneficial because nature favours quality over quantity. A more specified measure is ''motility grade'', where the motility of sperm are divided into four different grades:{{cite web|url=http://www.sharedjourney.com/define/semen2.html|title=Fertility Testing and Semen Analysis|publisher=}} * '''Grade a''': Sperm with progressive motility. These are the strongest and swim fast in a straight line. Sometimes it is also denoted motility '''IV'''. * '''Grade b''': (non-linear motility): These also move forward but tend to travel in a curved or crooked motion. Sometimes also denoted motility '''III'''. * '''Grade c''': These have non-progressive motility because they do not move forward despite the fact that they move their tails. Sometimes also denoted motility '''II'''. * '''Grade d''': These are immotile and fail to move at all. Sometimes also denoted motility '''I'''. [[File:Abnormalsperm.svg|thumb]] ===Morphology=== Regarding sperm [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]], the WHO criteria as described in 2010 state that a sample is normal (samples from men whose partners had a pregnancy in the last 12 months) if 4% (or 5th centile) or more of the observed sperm have normal morphology.{{cite journal |vauthors=Rothmann SA, Bort AM, Quigley J, Pillow R | title = Sperm morphology classification: a rational method for schemes adopted by the world health organization. | journal = Methods in Molecular Biology | volume = 927 | pages = 27–37 | year = 2013 | pmid = 22992901 | doi = 10.1007/978-1-62703-038-0_4 }} Morphology is a predictor of success in fertilizing oocytes during [[in vitro fertilization]]. Up to 10% of all spermatozoa have observable defects and as such are disadvantaged in terms of fertilising an oocyte.{{cite book|last=Sadler|first=T.|title=Langman's medical embryology.|year=2010|publisher=Lippincott William & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia|isbn=978-0-7817-9069-7|pages=30|edition=11th}} Also, sperm cells with tail-tip swelling patterns generally have lower frequency of [[aneuploidy]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Pang MG, You YA, Park YJ, Oh SA, Kim DS, Kim YJ | title = Numerical chromosome abnormalities are associated with sperm tail swelling patterns | journal = Fertil. Steril. | volume = 94 | issue = 3 | pages = 1012–1020 | date = June 2009 | pmid = 19505688 | doi = 10.1016/j.fertnstert.2009.04.043 | url = }} {{anchor|MSOME}} A ''motile sperm organelle morphology examination'' (MSOME) is a particular morphologic investigation wherein an inverted [[light microscope]] equipped with high-power optics and enhanced by digital imaging is used to achieve a magnification above x6000, which is much higher than the magnification used habitually by embryologists in spermatozoa selection for [[intracytoplasmic sperm injection]] (x200 to x400).{{cite journal |vauthors=Oliveira JB, Massaro FC, Mauri AL, Petersen CG, Nicoletti AP, Baruffi RL, Franco JG | title = Motile sperm organelle morphology examination is stricter than Tygerberg criteria | journal = Reproductive biomedicine online | volume = 18 | issue = 3 | pages = 320–326 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19298729 | doi = 10.1016/S1472-6483(10)60088-0 }} [http://www.crh.com.br/45.pdf]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} A potential finding on MSOME is the presence of sperm vacuoles, which are associated with sperm chromatin immaturity, particularly in the case of large vacuoles.{{cite journal |vauthors=Perdrix A, Rives N | title = Motile sperm organelle morphology examination (MSOME) and sperm head vacuoles: State of the art in 2013 | journal = Human Reproduction Update | volume = 19 | issue = 5 | pages = 527–541 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23825157 | pmc = | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dmt021 }} ===Volume=== According to one lab test manual semen volumes between 2.0 [[milliliters|mL]] and 5 mL are normal; WHO regards 1.5 ml as the lower [[reference limit]]. Low volume may indicate partial or complete blockage of the [[seminal vesicle]]s, or that the man was born without seminal vesicles. In clinical practice, a volume of less than 2 mL in the setting of infertility and absent sperm should prompt an evaluation for obstructive [[azoospermia]]. A caveat to this is be sure it has been at least 48 hours since the last ejaculation to time of sample collection. The human ejaculate is mostly composed of water. 96 to 98% of semen is water. One way of ensuring that a man produces more ejaculate{{cite web|title=How to increase your ejaculate|url=http://www.yellowsemen.com/how-to-cum-more/|accessdate=8 April 2017}} is to drink more liquids. Men also produce more seminal fluid after lengthy [[sexual stimulation]] and arousal. Reducing the frequency of sex and [[masturbation]] helps increase semen volume. [[Sexually-Transmitted Diseases|Sexually transmitted diseases]] also affect the production of semen. Men who are infected{{cite journal|title=Semen alterations in HIV-1 infected men|url=https://academic.oup.com/humrep/article/17/8/2112/603024/Semen-alterations-in-HIV-1-infected-men}} with the [[Human Immunodeficiency Virus|human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) produce lower semen volume. ===Color=== Semen normally has a whitish-gray color. It tends to get a yellowish tint as a man ages. Semen color is also influenced by the food we eat: foods that are high in sulfur, such as [[garlic]], may result in a man producing yellow semen.{{cite web|url=http://www.yellowsemen.com/causes-of-yellow-semen-and-yellow-sperm/|title=Causes of Yellow Semen and Yellow Sperm: What Color is Sperm?|date=12 April 2016|publisher=}} Presence of blood in semen ([[hematospermia]]) leads to a brownish or red colored ejaculate. Hematospermia is a rare condition. Semen that has a deep yellow color or is greenish in appearance may be due to medication. Brown semen is mainly a result of infection and inflammation of the prostate gland, [[urethra]], epididymis and seminal vesicles.{{Citation needed|reason=Original source does not contain this claim|date=March 2017}} Other causes of unusual semen color include sexually transmitted infections such as [[gonorrhea]] and [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]], genital surgery and injury to the male sex organs. ===Fructose level=== [[Fructose]] level in the semen may be analysed to determine the amount of energy available to the semen for moving. WHO specifies a normal level of 13 μ[[Mole (unit)|mol]] per sample. Absence of fructose may indicate a problem with the seminal vesicles. ===pH=== According to one lab test manual normal [[pH]] range is 7.1-8.0; WHO criteria specify normal as 7.2-7.8. Acidic ejaculate (lower pH value) may indicate one or both of the seminal vesicles are blocked. A basic ejaculate (higher pH value) may indicate an [[infection]]. A pH value outside of the normal range is harmful to sperm and affect their ability to penetrate the egg. ===Liquefaction=== The [[Liquification|liquefaction]] is the process when the gel formed by proteins from the seminal vesicles is broken up and the semen becomes more liquid. It normally takes less than 20 minutes for the sample to change from a thick [[gel]] into a [[liquid]]. In the [[National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence|NICE]] guidelines, a liquefaction time within 60 minutes is regarded as within normal ranges.{{cite web |url=http://www.nice.org.uk/nicemedia/pdf/CG011publicinfoenglish.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rhjtxNOs?url=http://www.nice.org.uk/nicemedia/pdf/CG011publicinfoenglish.pdf |archivedate=2010-08-03 |df= }} {{cite book |title=Fertility: Assessment and Treatment for People with Fertility Problems |publisher=RCOG Press |location=London |year=2004 |pages= |isbn=1-900364-97-2 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} ===MOT=== MOT is a measure of how many million sperm cells per ml are highly motile,{{cite web|url=https://dk.cryosinternational.com/resources/questions-answers#3219|title=Frequently asked questions|publisher=}} that is, approximately of grade a (>25 micrometer per 5 sek. at room temperature) and grade b (>25 micrometer per 25 sek. at room temperature). Thus, it is a combination of sperm count and motility. With a straw {{cite web|url=https://dk.cryosinternational.com/resources/questions-answers#3270|title=Frequently asked questions|publisher=}} or a vial volume of 0.5 milliliter, the general guideline is that, for [[intracervical insemination]] (ICI), straws or vials making a total of 20 million motile spermatozoa in total is recommended. This is equal to 8 straws or vials 0.5 ml with MOT5, or 2 straws or vials of MOT20. For [[intrauterine insemination]] (IUI), 1-2 MOT5 straws or vials is regarded sufficient.{{cite web|url=https://dk.cryosinternational.com/resources/questions-answers#3212|title=Frequently asked questions|publisher=}} In WHO terms, it is thus recommended to use approximately 20 million grade a+b sperm in ICI, and 2 million grade a+b in IUI. ===DNA damage=== DNA damage in sperm cells that is related to infertility can be probed by analysis of DNA susceptibility to denaturation in response to heat or acid treatment Evenson DP, Darzynkiewicz Z, Melamed MR. (1980) Relation of mammalian sperm chromatin heterogeneity to fertility. Science 210:1131-1133; {{PMID|7444440}} and/or by detection of [[DNA fragmentation]] revealed by the presence of double-strand breaks detected by the [[TUNEL assay]].Gorczyca W, Traganos F, Jesionowska H, Darzynkiewicz Z. (1993) Presence of DNA strand breaks and increased sensitivity of DNA in situ to denaturation in abnormal human sperm cells. Analogy to apoptosis of somatic cells. Exp Cell Res 207:202-205; {{PMID|8391465}}Evenson DP. (2017) Evaluation of sperm chromatin structure and DNA strand breaks is an important part of clinical male fertility assessment. Transl Androl Urol. Sep;6(Suppl 4):S495-S500. doi 10.21037/tau.2017.07.20. {{PMID|29082168}} ===Total motile spermatozoa=== ''Total motile spermatozoa'' (TMS){{cite journal |vauthors=Merviel P, Heraud MH, Grenier N, Lourdel E, Sanguinet P, Copin H | title = Predictive factors for pregnancy after intrauterine insemination (IUI): An analysis of 1038 cycles and a review of the literature | journal = Fertil. Steril. | volume = 93 | issue = 1 | pages = 79–88 | date = November 2008 | pmid = 18996517 | doi = 10.1016/j.fertnstert.2008.09.058 | url = }} or ''total motile sperm count'' (TMSC){{cite journal |vauthors=Pasqualotto EB, Daitch JA, Hendin BN, Falcone T, Thomas AJ, Nelson DR, Agarwal A | title = Relationship of total motile sperm count and percentage motile sperm to successful pregnancy rates following intrauterine insemination | journal = J. Assist. Reprod. Genet. | volume = 16 | issue = 9 | pages = 476–82 | date = October 1999 | pmid = 10530401 | pmc = 3455631 | doi = 10.1023/A:1020598916080 | url = http://www.kluweronline.com/art.pdf?issn=1058-0468&volume=16&page=476 }} is a combination of sperm count, motility and volume, measuring how many million sperm cells in an entire ejaculate are motile. Use of approximately 20 million sperm of motility grade c or d in ICI, and 5 million ones in IUI may be an approximate recommendation. ===Others=== The NICE guidelines also include testing ''vitality'', with normal ranges defined as more than 75% of sperm cells alive. The sample may also be tested for [[white blood cell]]s. A high level of white blood cells in semen is called {{visible anchor|leucospermia}} and may indicate an infection. [[Cutoff (reference value)|Cutoff]]s may vary, but an example cutoff is over 1 million white blood cells per milliliter of semen. ==Abnormalities== * [[Aspermia]]: absence of semen * [[Azoospermia]]: absence of sperm * [[Hypospermia]]: low semen volume * [[Hyperspermia]]: high semen volume * [[Oligozoospermia]]: Very low sperm count * [[Asthenozoospermia]]: poor sperm motility * [[Teratozoospermia]]: sperm carry more morphological defects than usual * [[Necrozoospermia]]: all sperm in the ejaculate are dead * ''Leucospermia'': a high level of white blood cells in semens ==Factors that influence results== Apart from the [[semen quality]] itself, there are various methodological factors that may influence the results, giving rise to [[inter-method variation]]. Compared to samples obtained from masturbation, semen samples from collection condoms have higher total sperm counts, sperm motility, and percentage of sperm with normal morphology {{Citation needed|date=October 2012}}. For this reason, they are believed to give more accurate results when used for semen analysis. If the results from a man's first sample are subfertile, they must be verified with at least two more analyses. At least 2 to 4 weeks must be allowed between each analysis.{{mcn|date=December 2017}} Results for a single man may have a large amount of natural variation over time, meaning a single sample may not be representative of a man's average semen characteristics.{{mcn|date=December 2017}} In addition, sperm physiologist Joanna Ellington believes that the stress of producing an ejaculate sample for examination, often in an unfamiliar setting and without any lubrication (most lubricants are somewhat harmful to sperm), may explain why men's first samples often show poor results while later samples show normal results.{{mcn|date=December 2017}} A man may prefer to produce his sample at home rather than at the clinic. The site of semen collection does ''not'' affect the results of a semen analysis.{{cite journal |vauthors=Licht RS, Handel L, Sigman M | title = Site of semen collection and its effect on semen analysis parameters | journal = Fertil. Steril. | volume = 89 | issue = 2 | pages = 395–7 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17482174 | doi = 10.1016/j.fertnstert.2007.02.033 }} ==Measurement methods== Volume can be determined by measuring the weight of the sample container, knowing the mass of the empty container. Sperm count and morphology can be calculated by microscopy. Sperm count can also be estimated by kits that measure the amount of a sperm-associated protein, and are suitable for home use.[https://archive.is/20120723092112/http://www.dailyprogress.com/cdp/news/local/article/charlottesville_company_sends_out_its_home_male_sterility_tests/40086/ dailyprogress.com > Charlottesville company sends out its home male sterility tests] By Brian McNeill. Published: May 14, 2009{{ums|date=December 2017}} '''''Computer Assisted Semen Analysis''''' (CASA) is a catch-all phrase for automatic or semi-automatic semen analysis techniques. Most systems are based on [[image analysis]], but alternative methods exist such as tracking cell movement on a [[digitizing tablet]].{{cite journal | author = Mortimer ST | title = CASA--practical aspects | journal = J. Androl. | volume = 21 | issue = 4 | pages = 515–24 | date = 1 July 2000 | pmid = 10901437 | url = http://www.andrologyjournal.org/cgi/reprint/21/4/515 | accessdate = 2007-08-05 }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Hinting A, Schoonjans F, Comhaire F | title = Validation of a single-step procedure for the objective assessment of sperm motility characteristics | journal = Int. J. Androl. | volume = 11 | issue = 4 | pages = 277–87 | year = 1988 | pmid = 3170018 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2605.1988.tb01001.x }} Computer-assisted techniques are most-often used for the assessment of sperm concentration and mobility characteristics, such as [[velocity]] and linear velocity. Nowadays, there are CASA systems, based on image analysis and using new techniques, with near perfect results, and doing full analysis in a few seconds. With some techniques, sperm concentration and motility measurements are at least as reliable as current manual methods.Testing of Accubead in: {{cite journal |vauthors=Tomlinson MJ, Pooley K, Simpson T, Newton T, Hopkisson J, Jayaprakasan K, Jayaprakasan R, Naeem A, Pridmore T | title = Validation of a novel computer-assisted sperm analysis (CASA) system using multitarget-tracking algorithms | journal = Fertil. Steril. | volume = 93 | issue = 6 | pages = 1911–20 | date = April 2010 | pmid = 19200972 | doi = 10.1016/j.fertnstert.2008.12.064 | url = }} '''[[Raman spectroscopy]]''' has made progress in its ability to perform characterization, identification and localization of sperm nuclear DNA damage.{{cite journal |vauthors=Mallidis C, Sanchez V, Wistuba J, Wuebbeling F, Burger M, Fallnich C, Schlatt S | title = Raman microspectroscopy: shining a new light on reproductive medicine | journal = Hum. Reprod. Update | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | pages = 403–14 | year = 2014 | pmid = 24144514 | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dmt055 | url = }} ==See also== * [[Semen quality]] * [[Artificial insemination]] for more details of how semen parameters affects pregnancy rate ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [http://www.webmd.com/men/guide/blood-in-semen-hematospermia-causes-symptoms-tests-treatments Blood in semen] Hematospermia * [http://labtestsonline.org/understanding/analytes/semen/tab/test Semen analysis] - Lab Tests Online * [http://www.gfmer.ch/Endo/Lectures_09/semen_analysis.htm Geneva Foundation for Medical Education and Research] - complete list of parameters. *[http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/publications/infertility/9789241547789/en/ WHO laboratory manual for the examination and processing of human semen Fifth edition 2010] - updated, standardized, evidence-based procedures and recommendations for laboratory analysis and quality control {{Male genital procedures}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Semen Analysis}} [[Category:Fertility medicine]] [[Category:Semen]]

{{EngvarB|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} '''Smoking in Ireland''' is [[smoking ban|banned]] fully in the [[employment|general workplace]], enclosed [[public space|public places]], restaurants, bars, [[education|education facilities]], [[hospital|healthcare facilities]] and public transport. However, it is permitted in designated [[hotel|hotel rooms]] and there is no ban in [[residential care]], prisons and in outdoor areas.<ref name="Tobacco overview">{{cite web | url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/tobacco/docs/tobacco_overview2011_en.pdf | title=Overview of smoke-free legislation in the EU | publisher=European Commission | date=May 2011 | accessdate=27 August 2013 | pages=8}}</ref> Public opinion is in favour of the bans on smoking imposed in Ireland.<ref name="Flash Eurobarometer poll">{{cite web | url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/archive/ph_determinants/life_style/tobacco/documents/eb_253_en.pdf | title=Survey on Tobacco Analytical report | publisher=European Commission | work=Gallup | date=March 2009 | accessdate=27 August 2013 | pages=56, 58, 60}}</ref>
== History == Currently, the Irish law prohibits smoking fully in the [[employment|general workplace]], enclosed [[public space|public places]], restaurants, bars, [[education|education facilities]], [[hospital|healthcare facilities]] and public transport. Smoking rooms are permitted in hotels.<ref name="Tobacco overview" />
As of July 2009, it is prohibited to advertise cigarettes and sell 10-packs of cigarettes in retail outlets. Additionally, as of February 2013, any tobacco product placed on the market must have graphic warnings.<ref name="Graphic photos" /> There is legislation being made to introduce [[plain tobacco packaging]] and make Ireland the second country to do so, after Australia.<ref name="Plain cigarette packets">{{cite news | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/plain-cigarette-packets-to-be-introduced-1.1408747 | title=Plain cigarette packets to be introduced | work=The Irish Times | date=28 May 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>
===Bans on smoking=== Smoking in workplaces in Ireland was banned on 29 March 2004, making Ireland the first country in the world to institute an outright ban on smoking in workplaces. From that date onwards, under the ''Public Health (Tobacco) Acts'', it has been illegal to smoke in all enclosed workplaces. The ban is strictly enforced and includes bars, restaurants, clubs, offices, public buildings, company cars, trucks, taxis and vans. A private residence is considered a workplace when tradespeople, such as plumbers or electricians, are working there. €3,000 is the maximum fine on the spot, while a prison sentence can also be given at a later time for violators. The law exempts dwellings, prisons, nursing homes, psychiatric wards, hotel rooms charitable accommodation and college dorm rooms. Certain buildings such as some hospitals forbid smoking anywhere in the grounds.
Before the 2004 law, smoking was already outlawed in public buildings, hospitals, schools, restaurant kitchens, cinemas, public pharmacies, public hairdressing premises, public banking halls, and on public transport aircraft and buses and some trains (Intercity trains provided smokers' carriages).<ref>[http://www.eu2004.ie/templates/standard.asp?sNavlocator=3,242,455 EU 2004 – "Smoking ban is first in world"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105210140/http://www.eu2004.ie/templates/standard.asp?sNavlocator=3%2C242%2C455 |date= 5 January 2008 }}</ref>
Premises must display a sign to inform patrons of the ban (in Irish or English), and the contact person for any complaints. A workplace can be given a fine of €3,000 for each person that is found smoking (this means €15,000 for 5 people in violation). Smoking rooms are not allowed. Any shelter can not have more than 50 percent coverage of walls. There is also a ''Compliance Line'' set up by the Office of Tobacco Control, that people can call to report people smoking in a workplace or retail outlets selling tobacco to under-18s.
On 18 July 2008, Irish [[Fine Gael]] MEP [[Avril Doyle]] proposed in a committee in the European Parliament, that she would like to see an EU-wide ban on cigarettes and cigars by 2025.<ref>EUObserver [http://euobserver.com/9/26515 MEP calls for EU ban on cigarettes by 2025] 18 July 2008</ref>
=== Cigarette packaging and advertising regulations === On 1 July 2009, Ireland banned in-store tobacco advertising and [[Tobacco display ban|displays of tobacco products]] at retail outlets and new controls on tobacco vending machines (limiting them to being token-operated in registered bars and clubs only) were also introduced. At the same time a ban on the sale of packets of 10 cigarettes was introduced. Tobacco advertising had already been banned from radio, television and on billboards beforehand. The changes now mean that tobacco products must now be stored out of sight in closed containers behind the counter (accessible by retail staff only) and customers can be shown a card showing all available brands in a pictorial list if they wish to purchase cigarettes. Signs must also be shown informing customers that tobacco is sold at the premises. Ireland was the first country in the EU and third in the world (after Canada and Iceland) to introduce such measures, which are punishable with a fine of €3,000 and/or a six-month prison sentence. However, specialist tobacco shops (of which there are fewer than six) are exempt from the new rules; all retailers selling tobacco must register with the [[Health Service Executive]] and the new laws will be enforced by environmental health officers.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
As of 1 February 2013, any tobacco product placed on the market must have graphic warnings.<ref name="Graphic photos">{{cite web | url=http://www.newstalk.ie/If-tobacco-were-discovered-today-it-would-not-be-a-legal-product | title=New graphic photos on Irish tobacco products from today | publisher=Newstalk | date=1 February 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013 | author=Roche, Sandra}}</ref> The [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health]], [[James Reilly (Irish politician)|Dr. James Reilly]]'s proposal to introduce [[plain tobacco packaging]] was approved by the [[Government of Ireland|Cabinet]] and expected legislation will be in place by early 2014.<ref name="Plain cigarette packets">{{cite news | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/plain-cigarette-packets-to-be-introduced-1.1408747 | title=Plain cigarette packets to be introduced | work=The Irish Times | date=28 May 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> As of September 2017 all cigarettes must remove all logos and feature plain packaging.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maynard|first=Olivia M.|last2=Brooks|first2=Jonathan C. W.|last3=Munafò|first3=Marcus R.|last4=Leonards|first4=Ute|date=2017-04-01|title=Neural mechanisms underlying visual attention to health warnings on branded and plain cigarette packs|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/add.13699/abstract|journal=Addiction|language=en|volume=112|issue=4|pages=662–672|doi=10.1111/add.13699|issn=1360-0443}}</ref>
==Public opinion== The public, according to a Flash Eurobarometer poll conducted by the Gallup Organisation in 2008 for the [[European Commission]], is in favour of a full ban on smoking in restaurants, bars, pubs, clubs, offices and other indoor workplaces.<ref name="Flash Eurobarometer poll">{{cite web | url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/archive/ph_determinants/life_style/tobacco/documents/eb_253_en.pdf | title=Survey on Tobacco Analytical report | publisher=European Commission | work=Gallup | date=March 2009 | accessdate=27 August 2013 | pages=56, 58, 60}}</ref>
{| border="1" class="wikitable" |+ Flash Eurobarometer poll from 2008 for the [[European Commission|EC]] <ref name="Flash Eurobarometer poll" /> ! ! {{flagicon|Italy}} Italy ! {{flagicon|Ireland}} '''Ireland''' ! {{flagicon|EU}} EU27 ! {{flagicon|Austria}} Austria ! {{flagicon|Czech Republic}} Czech Republic |- ! Totally in favour of ban in restaurants | 88.4% | '''77.9%''' | 62.5% | 37.6% | 58.4% |- ! Totally in favour of ban in bars, pubs and clubs | 86.5% | '''70.1%''' | 46.7% | 24.2% | 27.1% |- ! Totally in favour of ban in offices and other indoor workplaces | 88.3% | '''79.1%''' | 72.5% | 66% | 40.8% |}
According to the above poll there is a majority of people who support the ban on smoking introduced in 2004.
==Ban on smoking in private vehicles== Since 2009, Irish anti-smoking campaigners and scientists had been urging the government to introduce such a ban.<ref>[http://www.ash.ie/News/Latest_News/ASH_launch_campaign.html ASH Ireland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504133925/http://www.ash.ie/News/Latest_News/ASH_launch_campaign.html |date= 4 May 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.irishhealth.com/article.html?id=15119 Irish Health]</ref> In July 2011 the Minister for Health said that he was considering a ban where children are present in the car.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0727/breaking17.html?via=mr Children on board? Smoking in cars may be banned]</ref> On January 1st 2016, regulations make it an offence for a person to smoke in a private vehicle when there is more than one person present and there is a person under the age of 18 present. The offence would fall on the person smoking regardless of their age.<ref>[https://health.gov.ie/healthy-ireland/tobacco/smoking-in-cars-with-children-present/?via=mr Smoking banned in private vehicles with children onboard]</ref>
The senator and oncologist [[John Crown]] put a bill before parliament in 2012 to ban smoking in a car with children.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/picture-a-car-filled-with-secondhand-smoke-and-child-in-the-seat-3081119.html | work=Irish Independent | title=Picture a car filled with second-hand smoke and child in the seat | date=2 December 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=20997&&CatID=59]</ref> This bill was passed into law in December 2014 with an expectation that enforcement by Gardaí would commence in 2015.<ref>[http://www.oireachtas.ie/documents/bills28/acts/2014/a4014.pdf]</ref>
